LAKE PAT CLEBURNE
Part 1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 98.045 NAMED.
   The water reservoir located on the Nolan's River in Johnson County, Texas,
owned by the City, is named and shall be known and referred to as “Lake Pat
Cleburne.”
('68 Code, § 17-1) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.046 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   LAKE. Lake Pat Cleburne, as named in §
98.001.
   LAKE PAT CLEBURNE RESERVOIR AREA or RESERVOIR AREA. That area bounded by the
Lake Pat Cleburne Dam and the contour line of elevation 743 feet above mean sea
level, lying upstream from such dam.
('68 Code, § 17-2) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.047 APPLICATION.
   The provisions and regulations of this subchapter shall govern the
commercial, recreational, and other activities on the lake and lake property.
('68 Code, § 17-3) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.048 SUPERVISION.
   Except as otherwise provided, supervision of the entire lake property shall
be under the City Manager.
('68 Code, § 17-5) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.049 ESTABLISHMENT OF PARKS AND PICNIC AREAS.
   Certain areas adjacent to Lake Pat Cleburne shall be set aside and developed
by the city as public parks and picnic areas for use by the public.
('68 Code, § 17-6) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.050 COMMERCIAL AREAS AND CONCESSIONS.
   (A)   Areas at the lake shall be set aside for commercial purposes, such as
the rental of boats and motors and sale of bait and supplies. Any person to
whom a concession is let shall be responsible for observance of all rules and
regulations, and for the performance of such other duties as required by his
contract.
   (B)   Concessions may be let at the lake to any parties desiring to operate
a community boat house, public fishing pier, and other types as approved by the
City Council. Concession rights will be let on a bid basis. The number and
location of these facilities shall be controlled by the City Council.
('68 Code, § 17-7) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.051 BUOYS, FLOATS AND MARKERS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to install, keep, use or maintain any
buoy, float or marker in the waters of Lake Pat Cleburne made of metal, glass
or wood; except that it shall be lawful for the city to install, keep, use or
maintain buoys, floats and markers made of metal, glass or wood upon the waters
of the lake, for the purpose of marking areas restricted for reasons of safety
and for sanitation.
('68 Code, § 17-8) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.052 RESTRICTED AREAS.
   No person shall engage in wading, bathing, swimming, fishing, boating,
skiing, surfboarding, or any other activity in or upon Lake Pat Cleburne within
a quarter of a mile of the service spillway or any municipal water intake in
the lake.
('68 Code, § 17-9) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.053 RESTRICTED ZONE NEAR RAW WATER INTAKE.
   (A)   Upon the recommendation of the State Department of Health, a
restricted zone is established within a 200-foot radius of the raw water intake
on Lake Pat Cleburne. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter such
restricted zone and all recreational activities shall be prohibited therein.
   (B)   There shall be buoys and signs marking the restricted area established
in this section and signs setting out that a penalty will be imposed if such
zone is violated.
('68 Code, § 17-10(a),(b)) (Ord. passed 6-16-67)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.054 SWIMMING PERMITTED ONLY IN SPECIFIED AREAS.
   No person shall swim, wade, bathe or otherwise immerse himself in the waters
of Lake Pat Cleburne except in specified areas designated by the city.
('68 Code, § 17-11) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.055 RESERVED.
§ 98.056 TRESPASS ON DAM.
   No person shall, in any manner, go upon any part of the Lake Pat Cleburne
Dam for any purpose.
('68 Code, § 17-13) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.057 STRUCTURES PROHIBITED IN RESERVOIR AREA; EXCEPTIONS.
   No duck blinds, ski jumps, or other structures of whatever nature shall be
constructed or placed in the Lake Pat Cleburne reservoir area; provided,
however, that this section shall not preclude the construction of piers and
boathouses in the manner provided in this subchapter.
('68 Code, § 17-14) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.058 SEWAGE SYSTEM FOR DWELLINGS WITHIN 1,300 FEET OF SERVICE SPILLWAY
LEVEL.
   All habitations located within 1,300 feet of the service spillway level
(elevation 733.5 feet above mean sea level) in Lake Pat Cleburne shall be
connected to a municipal sanitary sewer system, or shall be connected to an
approved septic tank, the minimum requirements for which shall be as follows:
   (A)   Tank prefabricated, 500 gallons.
   (B)   Lateral lines, vitrified clay, shall be 250 feet or more in length,
shall be equipped with a distribution box, and shall be installed in a manner
approved by the City Engineer.
   (C)   Inspection shall be made by a City Engineering Department
representative before the tank and lines are covered.
   (D)   The lowest point in the lateral system shall be at least 737.5 feet
above mean sea level in elevation.
   (E)   No part of such system shall be less than 150 feet (measured
horizontally) from the spillway level.
   (F)   Installations serving more than one dwelling unit, or any type of
commercial installation, shall be installed in a manner approved by the City
Engineer.
('68 Code, § 17-15) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.059 WASTE FROM INDUSTRIES, SLAUGHTERHOUSES AND THE LIKE WITHIN WATERSHED.
   If industries are contemplated to be established within the Lake Pat
Cleburne watershed, approval of the proposed project by the Texas State
Department of Public Health and the Health Department of the city concerning
the treatment of wastes is deemed necessary to prevent undesirable conditions
from occurring. No slaughterhouses, markets, or meat shops where hogs, beeves,
or other animals or fowls are slaughtered shall be located where any refuse;
discharge or contents thereof of any nature whatsoever shall be discharged into
the lake or its watershed.
('68 Code, § 17-16) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.060 RESTRICTIONS ON ANIMALS AND ANIMAL PENS OR BARNS.
   No animals or livestock shall be permitted nearer to Lake Pat Cleburne than
the emergency spillway level (elevation 743.4 feet above mean sea level). No
animal pens, corrals or barns shall be constructed within 300 feet (measured
horizontally) of such emergency spillway elevation, nor shall they be
constructed at any point from which drainage may run into Lake Pat Cleburne or
into any stream which lies within the lake watershed.
('68 Code, § 17-17) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.061 LAND FILLS.
   No filling of land with dirt, rock or any other material shall be permitted
in the Reservoir below an elevation of 743.4 feet above mean sea level without
the written permission of the City Council.
('68 Code, § 17-18) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.062 DEPOSIT OF GARBAGE, TRASH AND THE LIKE PROHIBITED.
   No garbage, trash, refuse, dead animal, fish, vegetable, food, ashes, offal,
fecal matter, cans, bottles, glass, rubbish or filth of any kind shall be
placed or be permitted to be placed in the waters of Lake Pat Cleburne or
situated in such a manner that it will drain toward or reach the waters of Lake
Pat Cleburne.
('68 Code, § 17-19) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.063 DESTRUCTION OF PROPERTY ON LAKE.
   Any person who shall wilfully or mischievously injure or destroy property of
any description on Lake Pat Cleburne shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
('68 Code, § 17-20) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.064 HUNTING AND DISCHARGE OR POSSESSION OF FIREARMS PROHIBITED.
   Hunting or the discharge of firearms of any type whatever or the possession
of firearms on Lake Pat Cleburne is prohibited.
('68 Code, § 17-21) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.065 SKIING, SURFBOARDING AND THE LIKE.
   The activities of skiing, surfboarding and other comparable water sports on
the lake shall be governed as follows:
   (A)   All persons directly engaged in such activities shall wear life
preservers at all times.
   (B)   Boats towing persons engaged in such activities shall go no nearer
than 200 feet of docks, swimming areas or fishermen.
   (C)   Such activities shall not be engaged in from the period of one hour
after sunset to one hour prior to sunrise, nor shall any person operate a boat
for the purpose of towing persons engaged in such activities from the period of
one hour after sunset to one hour prior to sunrise; provided, that this
provision shall not apply to boats, craft and individuals participating in duly
authorized ski tournaments, competitions, exhibitions or trials therefor, where
adequate lighting is provided.
   (D)   Any boat or other craft towing persons engaged in such activities must
be occupied by at least two people, one to observe the persons engaged in such
activity and the other to operate the boat or other craft.
   (E)   No tow boat or person engaged in any such activity shall approach
closer than 150 feet to any other boat or craft when proceeding at speed.
   (F)   Such activities shall not be engaged in north of Country Club Road.
   (G)   No boat or other craft shall follow closer than 200 feet behind a
person engaged in any such activity.
('68 Code, § 17-22) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.066 CHILDREN UNDER 12 TO BE ACCOMPANIED BY ADULT.
   No child under the age of 12 years shall be permitted to enter or remain in
or upon Lake Pat Cleburne unless accompanied by and under the immediate
supervision at all times of some adult person.
('68 Code, § 17-23) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.067 ORDERING PERSONS ASHORE DUE TO WEATHER.
   When, in the opinion of the City Manager or his authorized representative,
severe weather is forecast or when weather conditions on the lake are such as
to render boating, fishing, swimming and other activities hazardous, he shall
have the authority to order all persons and all boats and other craft ashore,
under such terms and conditions as, in the sole judgment of the City Manager or
his representative, are deemed necessary for the protection of life, limb and
property. Any person failing to obey such instructions under such circumstances
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
('68 Code, § 17-24) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.068 OBEDIENCE TO INSTRUCTIONS, WARNINGS AND SIGNS RELATING TO LAKE.
   No person shall fail or refuse to obey any lawful instruction or warning
issued by many police officer or other authorized representative of the city,
in enforcing the provisions of this subchapter, nor shall any person fail or
refuse to obey any instruction or warning displayed upon any sign erected at
the lake by the city.
('68 Code, § 17-25) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.069 WAIVER OF CHAPTER PROVISIONS FOR SPECIAL EVENTS.
   The City Council may, upon application and after hearing, waive for a
specified length of time such of the terms, provisions and conditions of this
subchapter as may be deemed appropriate for the accommodation of water
carnivals, shows, boat races, swimming meets, educational purposes, exhibitions
and other special events as may be permitted from time to time, and subject to
such safety measures as the City Council may require.
('68 Code, § 17-26) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.070 CITY NOT LIABLE FOR DAMAGES; USE OF LAKE SUBJECT OTHER REGULATIONS.
   The city shall in no event be liable to any person on account of the loss or
damage to any property that may be placed in or upon Lake Pat Cleburne, nor
shall the city be liable in any event to any person or persons whomsoever on
account of personal injuries or loss of life that may be sustained by any
person in or upon the lake, and any person entering in or upon the lake shall
do so at his or her sole risk, and shall not be privileged to enter or remain
in or upon the lake save and except under the terms and provisions of this
chapter and such other applicable code provision, ordinance, resolution and
regulation that have been, or may hereafter be, adopted by the city.
('68 Code, § 17-27) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.071 ENFORCEMENT OF LAW RELATING TO LAKE.
   It shall be the duty of the police to patrol Lake Pat Cleburne and the
adjoining lands for the purpose of enforcing strict compliance on the part of
all persons with the terms, provisions and conditions of this chapter and all
other laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of the city relating to the lake,
and to make arrests upon the violation of any ordinance, code provision or
regulation of the city.
('68 Code, § 17-28) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.072 EXCLUSION OF VIOLATORS.
   Any police officer, or other authorized representative of the city shall
have the right and authority to exclude from the premises any person in or upon
the lake in violation of the terms and provisions of this chapter.
('68 Code, § 17-29) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.073 REVOCATION OF LICENSES AND PERMITS.
   The City Manager shall have full power to revoke any license or permit
issued under this chapter for the violation or infringement of the rules or
regulations prescribed in this chapter. If for any reason a person's license or
permit is revoked, he or she shall have the right to appeal the revocation to
the City Council. Any such revocation shall be in addition to any penalty
imposed for such violation.
('68 Code, § 17-30) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.074 OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES PROHIBITED EXCEPT IN DESIGNATED AREAS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in the
Lake Pat Cleburne Reservoir Area except on a roadway or parking area designated
for motor vehicles.
   (B)   The provisions of this section do not apply to a city employee in the
performance of an official duty.
   (C)   For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      MOTOR VEHICLE. Every vehicle which is self-propelled.
      VEHICLE. Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or
may be transported upon a public highway, except devices moved by human power.
   (D)   All rights and remedies of the city are expressly saved as to any and
all violations of the provisions of any other ordinances affecting conduct at
Lake Pat Cleburne Reservoir which have accrued at the time of the effective
date of this section; and, as to such accrued violations and all pending
litigation, both civil and criminal, whether pending in court or not, under
such ordinances same shall not be affected by this section but may be
prosecuted until final disposition by the courts.
(Ord. 06-2009-35, passed 6-23-09) Penalty, see §
98.999
Part 2: BOATS
§ 98.080 BOATS — INSPECTION AND APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL.
   It shall be the duty of the City Manager or his authorized representatives
to inspect all boats and other craft before the same are permitted to be placed
on Lake Pat Cleburne, and to issue to the owner or person in charge thereof a
certificate of approval or disapproval. If for any reason such officer should
be of the opinion that any boat or other craft is unsafe and unworthy or
dangerous to life, a certificate of disapproval shall be issued which fully
states the reasons for such disapproval, and the owner of or person in charge
of such boat or other craft shall have the right to submit such matter to the
City Council, whose decision shall in all cases be final.
('68 Code, § 17-42) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.081 HOUSE BOATS, AIR BOATS, RAFTS AND BARGES PROHIBITED; EXCEPTION; OTHER
BOATS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall place, operate, or keep any craft commonly referred to
as a house boat, air boat, raft or barge on Lake Pat Cleburne; provided,
however, that the City Manager may grant, for a period not to exceed 30 days,
permission to use a raft or barge on the lake for construction, dredging and
other like purposes, and nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the
city and its authorized representatives from using rafts and barges for the
operation and maintenance of the lake.
   (B)   No boat shall be operated on Lake Pat Cleburne that exceeds the
centerline length-power ratio listed below:
                  Maximum Horse Power

('68 Code, § 17-43) (Ord. passed 8-11-64; Am. Ord. passed 9-9-69)

§ 98.082 BOATS TO BE SELF SUSTAINING; EXCEPTION.
   No boat or other craft shall be operated on Lake Pat Cleburne unless the
same is self sustaining, either by patent methods, compartmentation or
composition. Inboard power boats shall be excepted from this section.
('68 Code, § 17-44) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.083 BOAT LIGHTS.
   (A)   A vessel or motorboat when not at dock must have and exhibit at least
one bright light, lantern, or flashlight from sunset to sunrise in all weather.
A vessel or motorboat when underway between sunset and sunrise in all weather
must have and exhibit the lights prescribed below for boats of its class. No
other lights that may be mistaken for those prescribed may be exhibited.
   (B)   Each class A and class 1 motorboat must have the following lights:
      (1)   A bright white light aft to show all around the horizon; and
      (2)   A combined lantern in the fore part of the vessel and lower than
the white light aft, showing green to starboard and red to port, so fixed as to
throw the light from right ahead to two points abaft the beam on their
respective sides.
   (C)   Each class 2 and class 3 motorboat must have the following lights and
light screens:
      (1)   A bright white light in the fore part of the vessel as near the
stem as practicable, so constructed as to show an unbroken light over an arc of
the horizon of 20 points of the compass and so fixed as to throw the light 10
points on each side of the vessel, namely from right ahead to two points abaft
the beam on either side;
      (2)   A bright white light aft to show all around the horizon and higher
than the white light forward;
      (3)   A green light on the starboard side so constructed as to show an
unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 10 points of the compass and so
fixed as to throw the light from right ahead to two points abaft the beam on
the starboard side;
      (4)   A red light on the port side so constructed as to show an unbroken
light over an arc of the horizon of 10 points of the compass and so fixed as to
throw the light right ahead to two points abaft the beam on the port side; and
      (5)   Inboard screens fitted on the starboard and port side lights of
sufficient length and so set as to prevent the side lights from being seen
across the bow.
   (D)   Each class A and class 1 motorboat when propelled by sail alone must
have the combined lantern but not the white light aft prescribed in division
(B) of this section.
   (E)   Each class 3 and class 3 motorboat when propelled by sail alone must
have the colored side lights, suitably screened, but not the white lights
prescribed in division (C) of this section.
   (F)   Motorboats of all classes when propelled by sail alone must have ready
at hand a lantern or flashlight showing a white light which shall be exhibited
in sufficient time to prevent collision.
   (G)   A white light required by this section must be visible at a distance
of at least two miles. A colored light required by this section must be visible
at a distance of at least one mile. In this section, VISIBLE means visible on
dark nights with a clear atmosphere.
   (H)   A motorboat propelled by sail and machinery must have the lights
required by this section for motorboats propelled by machinery alone.
   (I)   A motorboat may have and exhibit the lights required by the
Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea, 1948, Act of October 11, 1951,
current provisions being 33 USC 1601 et seq., as amended, instead of the lights
specified in this section.
(Tex. Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.064) ('68 Code, § 17-45) (Ord. passed 8-11-
64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.084 SEARCH LIGHTING.
   No person shall flash searchlights on the bridge of a boat or other craft
being operated on Lake Pat Cleburne.

§ 98.085 LIFE PRESERVERS.
   (A)   A motorboat must have at least one life preserver, life belt, ring
buoy, or other device of the sort prescribed by the regulations of the
commandant of the Coast Guard for each person on board, so placed as to be
readily accessible.
   (B)   A motorboat carrying passengers for hire must have a readily
accessible life preserver of the sort prescribed by the regulations of the
commandant of the Coast Guard for each person on board.
   (C)   The operator of a class A or class 1 motorboat, while underway, shall
require every passenger under 13 years of age to wear a life preserver of the
sort prescribed by the regulations of the commandant of the Coast Guard. A life
belt or ring buoy does not satisfy this requirement.
(Tex. Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.066) ('68 Code, § 17-47) (Ord. passed 8-11-
64)

   No person may operate a motorboat of over 15 horsepower on the public waters
of this state unless the person is 13 years of age or older, or is accompanied

safety course prescribed and approved by the department.

§ 98.093 LAUNCHING PERMITTED ONLY AT AUTHORIZED POINTS.
   No person shall launch a boat or other craft on Lake Pat Cleburne except at

('68 Code, § 17-55) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.094 TRAFFIC RULES.
   (A)   Generally. The traffic rules prescribed in this section shall be
observed by boats and other craft operating on Lake Pat Cleburne.
   (B)   Passing. When two boats or other craft are approaching each other
“head-on” or nearly so (so as to involve risk of collision), it shall be the
duty of each boat to bear to the right and pass the other boat on its left
side.
   (C)   Crossing. When boats approach each other obliquely or at right angles,
the boat approaching on the right side has the right-of-way.
   (D)   Overtaking. One boat may overtake another on either side, but must
grant the right-of-way to the overtaken boat.
   (E)   Rules of the road. Except as otherwise expressly provided herein, the
rules of the road as applicable to U.S. Coast Guard Inland Waterways, as the
same now are, or as the same may be amended, applicable to the operation of
small boats, are hereby adopted and made a part hereof.
('68 Code, § 17-56) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.095 RECKLESS DRIVING AND SPEEDING.
   (A)   Every operator of a boat or other craft on Lake Pat Cleburne shall at
all times navigate the same in a careful and prudent manner and at such rate of
speed as not to endanger the life, limb or property of any person.
   (B)   Reckless navigation of any boat or other craft on Lake Pat Cleburne
shall include operating the same in a manner which unnecessarily interferes
with the free and proper use of the water of the lake or unnecessarily
endangers other boats and craft therein, or the life and limb of any person.
   (C)   No person shall operate any boat or other craft on Lake Pat Cleburne
at a rate of speed greater than will permit, by the exercise of reasonable
care, such boat to be brought to a stop within the assured clear distance
ahead.
('68 Code, § 17-57) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.096 OPERATION UNDER THE INFLUENCE; HABITUAL USER OF LIQUOR, DRUGS OR
BARBITURATES.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE. This term has the meaning assigned by Tex. Alcoholic
Beverages Code § 1.04.
   ALCOHOL CONCENTRATION. This term means:
      (1)   The number of grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood;
      (2)   The number of grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath; or
      (3)   The number of grams of alcohol per 67 milliliters of urine.
   CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE. This term has the meaning assigned by Tex. Health and
Safety Code § 481.002.
   CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE ANALOGUE. This term has the meaning assigned by Tex.
Health and Safety Code § 481.002.
   DRUG. This term has the meaning assigned by Tex. Health and Safety Code §
481.002.
   INTOXICATED. This term means:
      (1)   Not having the normal use of mental or physical faculties by reason
of the introduction of alcohol, a controlled substance, a controlled substance
analogue, a drug, or a combination of two or more of those substances into the
body; or
      (2)   Having an alcohol concentration of 0.10 or more.
   SERIOUS BODILY INJURY. Injury that creates a substantial risk of death or
that causes serious temporary or permanent disfigurement or protracted loss or
impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ.
   (B)   No person may operate a moving vessel or manipulate water skis, an
aquaplane, or a similar device while the person is intoxicated. For the purpose
of this section, a vessel does not include any device that is propelled solely
by the current of the water. A person who violates this subsection commits an
offense.
   (C)   Except as provided by divisions (D), (E), and (F) of this section, an
offense under division (B) of this section is punishable by:
      (1)   A fine not less than $100 or more than $1000;
      (2)   Confinement in jail for a term not to exceed 180 days; or
      (3)   Both the fine and confinement in jail.
   (D)   If it is shown at the trial of a person that the person has previously
been convicted once of an offense under division (B) of this section, the
offense is punishable by:
      (1)   A fine of not less than $300 or more than $2,000;
      (2)   Confinement in jail for a term not to exceed one year; or
      (3)   Both the fine and confinement in jail.
   (E)   If it is shown at the trial of a person that the person has previously
been convicted two or more times of an offense under division (B) of this
section, the offense is punishable by:
      (1)   A fine of not less than $500 or more than $2,000; and
      (2)   Confinement in jail for a term of not less than 30 days or more
than two years or imprisonment in the state penitentiary for a term of not less
than 60 days or more than five years.
   (F)   A conviction under division (B) of this section may not be used for
the purpose of enhancement under division (D) or (E) if:
      (1)   The conviction was for an offense committed more than five years
before the offense for which the person is being tried was committed; and
      (2)   The person has not been convicted of an offense under division (B)
committed within five years immediately preceding the date on which the offense
for which the person is being tried was committed.
   (G)   If it is shown at the trial of a person punished for an offense under
division (C), (D), or (E) of this section that the person committed the offense
and as a direct result of the offense another person suffered serious bodily
injury, the minimum term of confinement for the offense is increased by 60 days
and the minimum and maximum fines for the offense are increased by $500.
   (H)   A person who operates a moving vessel or manipulates water skis, an
aquaplane, or a similar device is deemed to have given consent, subject to this
section, to the taking of one or more specimens of the person's breath or blood
for the purpose of analysis to determine the alcohol concentration or the
presence in the person's body of a controlled substance, controlled substance
analogue, or drug if the person is arrested for any offense arising out of acts
alleged to have been committed while the person was operating or in actual
physical control of a moving vessel or manipulating water skis, an aquaplane,
or a similar device while intoxicated. A person so arrested may consent to the
giving of any other type of specimen to determine the person's alcohol
concentration, but the person is not deemed, solely on the basis of the
person's operation of a moving vessel or manipulating water skis, an aquaplane,
or a similar device, to have given consent to give any specimen other than a
specimen of the person's breath or blood. The specimen or specimens shall be
taken at the request of a peace officer having probable cause to believe the
person was operating or in actual physical control of a moving vessel or
manipulating water skis, an aquaplane, or a similar device while intoxicated.
   (I)   When a person gives a specimen of blood at the request or order of a
peace officer under this section, only a physician, qualified technician,
chemist, registered professional nurse, or licensed vocational nurse may
withdraw a blood specimen for the purpose of determining the alcohol
concentration or presence of a controlled substance, controlled substance
analogue, or drug in the blood. The sample must be taken in a sanitary place
inspected periodically by the county in which the sample is taken or in a
physician's office or a hospital licensed by the Texas Department of Health.
This limitation does not apply to the taking of specimens of breath, urine, or
bodily substances other than blood. The person drawing the blood specimen at
the request or order of a peace officer under this section or the hospital
where that person is taken for the purpose of securing the blood specimen is
not liable for damages arising from the request or order of the peace officer
to take the blood specimen as provided by this section, if the blood specimen
was withdrawn according to recognized medical procedures This division does not
relieve a person from liability for negligence in withdrawing a blood specimen.
Breath specimens taken at the request or order of a peace officer must be taken
and analysis made under conditions prescribed by division (B), Section 3,
Chapter 434, Acts of the 61st Legislature, Regular Session, 1969 , being Tex.
Rev. Civ. Stat., Art. 6701l-5.
   (J)   A person who gives a specimen of breath, blood, urine, or other bodily
substance under this section may, on request and within a reasonable time not
to exceed two hours after the arrest, have a physician, qualified technician,
chemist, or registered professional nurse of the person's own choosing draw a
specimen and have an analysis made of the person's blood in addition to any
specimen taken and analyzed at the direction of a peace officer. The failure or
inability to obtain an additional specimen or analysis by a person does not
preclude the admission of evidence relating to the analysis of the specimen
taken at the direction of the peace officer under this section.
   (K)   On the request of a person who has given a specimen at the request of
a peace officer, full information concerning the analytical results of the test
or tests of the specimen shall be made available to the person or the person's
attorney.
   (L)   If for any reason the person's request to have a chemical test is
refused by the officer or any other person acting for or on behalf of the
state, that fact may be introduced into evidence at the person's trial.
   (M) If the person refuses a request by an officer to give a specimen of
breath or blood, whether the refusal is express or the result of an intentional
failure of the person to give the specimen, that fact may be introduced into
evidence at the person's trial.
   (N)   Before requesting a person to give a specimen, the officer shall
inform the person orally and in writing that if the person refuses to give the
specimen that refusal may be admissible in a subsequent prosecution. The
officer shall provide the person with a written statement containing this
information. If the person refuses the request of the officer to give a
specimen, the officer shall request the person to sign a statement that the
officer requested that the person give a specimen, that the person was informed
of the consequence of not giving a specimen, and that the person refused to
give a specimen.
   (O)   Except as provided by division (Q) of this section, if a person under
arrest refuses upon request of a peace officer to give a specimen designated by
the peace officer as provided by division (H), a specimen may not be taken.
   (P)   A person who is dead, unconscious, or otherwise in a condition
rendering the person incapable of refusal, whether the person is arrested or
not, is deemed not to have withdrawn the consent provided by division (H) of
this section. If the person is dead, a specimen may be withdrawn by the county
medical examiner or the examiner's designated agent or, if there is no county
medical examiner for the county, by a licensed funeral director or a person
authorized as provided by division (I) of this section. If the person is not
dead but is incapable of refusal, a specimen may be withdrawn by a person
authorized as provided by division (I) of this section. Evidence of alcohol
concentration or the presence of a controlled substance, controlled substance
analogue, or drug obtained by an analysis authorized by this division is
admissible in a civil or criminal action.
   (Q)   A peace officer shall require a person to give a specimen if:
      (1)   The officer arrests the person for an offense under Tex. Penal Code
§ 19.05(2)(a) or this section;
      (2)   The person is the operator of a vessel involved in an accident that
the officer reasonably believes occurred as a result of the offense;
      (3)   At the time of the arrest the officer reasonably believes that a
person has died or will die as a direct result of the accident; and
      (4)   The person refuses the officer's request to give a specimen
voluntarily.
(Tex. Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.097) ('68 Code, § 17-58) (Ord. passed 8-11-
64)
Penalty, see § 98.999

shall permit same to carry intoxicating liquor.

§ 98.099 RIDING ON DECKS AND GUNWALES.
   No person operating a motor boat on Lake Pat Cleburne shall allow any person
to ride or sit on the gunwales thereof or on the decking over the bow of the
craft while underway, nor shall any person operating an open motor boat allow
any person to stand in the craft while underway. Nothing in this section shall
be construed to mean that passengers or other persons aboard a boat cannot
stand on the decking over the bow of the boat to moor the boat or to cast off
or for any other necessary purpose.
('68 Code, § 17-61) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)

on Lake Pat Cleburne in such a position as to obstruct a passageway ordinarily
used by other boats and craft.

§ 98.101 MOORING TO BUOYS, BEACONS OR SIGNS.

or sign placed on Lake Pat Cleburne by the city, nor shall any person in any

§ 98.102 ANCHORING.
   No person shall leave a boat or other craft on Lake Pat Cleburne without
having same dependably fastened to an anchorage, either in the water or upon
the land, or any such boat or other craft must be removed from the water a
sufficient distance to assure that the same will not be caused to float away
from its station because of rising waters.
('68 Code, § 17-64) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.103 OVERLOADING.
   No person owning or operating a boat or other craft on Lake Pat Cleburne
shall permit the came to be occupied by more persons than the rated capacity of
such boat or other craft, nor shall any person owning or operating a craft on
Lake Pat Cleburne permit the same to be loaded with passengers or cargo beyond
its safe capacity, taking into consideration weather and other operating
conditions.
('68 Code, § 17-65) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.104 ACCIDENTS.
   (A)   Duty of operators. The operator of a vessel involved in a collision,
accident, or casualty shall:
      (1)   Render to other persons affected such assistance as may be
practicable and necessary in order to save them from or minimize any danger
insofar as he or she can do so without serious danger to his or her own vessel,
crew, and passengers; and
      (2)   Give his or her name, address, and identification of his or her
vessel in writing to any person injured and to the owner of any property
damaged in the collision, accident, or other casualty.
   (B)   Accident reports.
      (1)   The operator of a vessel involved in a collision, accident, or
other casualty that results in death or injury to a person or damage to
property in excess of $500 shall file with the department on or before the
expiration of 30 days after the incident a full description of the collision,
accident, or casualty in accordance with regulations established by the
department.
      (2)   The accident reports are confidential and are inadmissible in court
as evidence.
      (3)   On request made by an authorized official or agency of the United
States, any information available to the department under division (B)(1) of
this section shall be sent to the official or agency.
(Tex. Parks and Wildlife Code §§ 31.104 and 31.105) ('68 Code, § 17-66) (Ord.
passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.105 REMOVAL OF BOATS FROM LAKE.
   (A)   The City Manager and any police officer may require the removal of any
boat or other craft from Lake Pat Cleburne if:
      (1)   Such boat or other craft is in an unsafe operating condition.
      (2)   Such boat or other craft is in violation of any of the applicable
provisions of this subchapter
   (B)   Any person refusing to, remove any boat or other craft under the
provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
('68 Code, § 17-67) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.106 DERELICTS.
   Any boat or other craft found abandoned or adrift on Lake Pat Cleburne, or
any unlicensed boat or other craft thereon, or any boat or other craft, not in
use, found not anchored or grounded in compliance with this subchapter, shall
be deemed to be a derelict, and shall be taken up by the City Manager or any
police officer, and the city shall have a lien thereon for all unpaid license
fees and the expenses of taking, towing and keeping the same, which shall be
done at the owner's risk, and without any liability whatsoever on the part of
the city.
('68 Code, § 17-68) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
Part 3: FISHING
§ 98.115 FISHING — APPLICABILITY OF STATE LAW.
   The general laws of the state, as the same are now or as they may hereafter
be amended, save and except as specifically provided through proper ordinances
and regulations passed by the city, will control the taking of fish from Lake
Pat Cleburne.
Penalty, see § 98.999
('68 Code, § 17-79) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
§ 98.116 FISHING PROHIBITED NEAR INTAKE TOWER.
   Fishing shall not be allowed within one-fourth mile of the intake tower.
('68 Code, § 17-80) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.117 PERMITTED FISHING EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful, in Lake Pat Cleburne, for any person to catch,
take, or attempt to catch or take any fish, or possess any fish taken by any
method, means or device, except by ordinary pole and line, rod and reel, fly
rod, throw line equipped with no more than 50 hooks. The use of trotlines is
limited to one trotline per person and no metallic trotlines shall be used. All
trotlines shall have valid bear tags attached within three feet of the first
hook at each end of the trotline. No two trotlines, or more, shall be connected
together in any manner and no trotlines shall be within 200 feet of any boat,
dock or pier, bathing pier, or any place commonly used as a swimming or ski
area. It shall be unlawful for any person to fish for, take, catch or attempt
to catch any fish in the waters of Lake Pat Cleburne, by any net, seine, snag
line, trap, or any other device not herein authorized by this section within
200 yards of the lake shall be prima facie evidence of violation of this
section.
   (B)   Notwithstanding the above provisions, rough fish may be taken with
cast net or legal minnow seine, or with seines and nets the meshes of which are
not less than one inch square, or with wire, rope or gig, but no person shall
possess other fish when using much devices.
('68 Code, § 17-81) (Ord. passed 8-11-64; Am. Ord. 4-1976-17, passed 4-30-76;
Am. Ord. 7-1993-25, passed 7-13-93)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.118 DESTRUCTION OF ABANDONED OR UNLAWFUL EQUIPMENT.
   Any net, seine, snag line, trap, float, trotline of metal or any trotline
left unattended for 30 or more days, or any other device found in the waters of
Lake Pat Cleburne, in violation of this subchapter, is declared to be a
nuisance, and it shall be the duty of any police officer to destroy the same
whenever found, and no suit shall be maintained against him therefor.
('68 Code, § 17-82) (Ord. passed 8-11-64; Am. Ord. 7-1993-25, passed 7-13-93)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.119 PROHIBITED BAIT.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to use any game fish or fresh water
rough fish, including fish commonly known as gold fish and carp, as bait in
Lake Pat Cleburne, except that such fish may be cut up and used as cut bait.
('68 Code, § 17-83) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.120 COMMERCIAL FISHING PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or buy, or to offer to. sell or
buy, or take or possess, for commercial purposes, fish from the waters of Lake
Pat Cleburne.
('68 Code, § 17-84) (Ord. passed 8-11-64)
Penalty, see § 98.999
Part 4: PIERS AND BOATHOUSES
§ 98.125 APPLICATION OF BUILDING CODE.
   Piers, docks, and boathouses at the lake are “structures,” as that term is
used in the city’s building code set forth in
Chapter 150 of this code, and persons desiring to construct them shall comply
in all respects with such code.
(‘68 Code, § 17-95) (Ord. passed 8-11-64; Am. Ord. 11-2021-65, passed 11-9-21)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.126 GENERAL ISSUES AFFECTING BOAT DOCKS/LAKE ACCESS SITES.
   No pier, dock, or boathouse will be permitted to be built on the lake that
adversely impacts the water quality, or the general use and activities on Lake
Pat Cleburne. As such, due care and diligence shall be exercised by the City
Council of the City of Cleburne in considering requested permits for any pier,
dock, or boathouse in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 11-2021-65, passed 11-9-21)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.127 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall keep, maintain, erect, construct, enlarge, alter, or move
any pier, dock, or boathouse, or any combination of such structures on the Lake
Pat Cleburne Reservoir Area, nor shall any person cause any of said acts to be
done, without first obtaining a permit for such structure.
(‘68 Code, § 17-112) (Ord. passed 8-11-64; Am. Ord. 11-2021-65, passed 11-9-21
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.128 PIER, DOCK, AND BOATHOUSE PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   The following is required for consideration of a pier, dock, or boathouse
permit:
   (A)   A land use easement or license agreement allowing for the use of the
land on which the structure is to be placed.
   (B)   A survey prepared by a State of Texas registered land surveyor showing
the water frontage of the lot subject to the permit application, mean high or
ordinary water lines, property lines, and the width of waterway.
   (C)   Plans showing the height, width, and length of all proposed structures
to include pilings, boat lifts, platforms, pavilions, detail and construction
specifications, and all other information deemed necessary by the Building
Official to properly evaluate the plan. The design, construction, alteration,
and repair of the pier, dock, or boathouse shall conform to the provisions of
this chapter as amended or superseded from time to time. Pile dimensions,
spacing, and embedment shall be designed according to best engineering
practices. Materials used in the construction of a pier, dock, or boathouse
shall be made of nontoxic, nonpollutant materials which will not harm the
environment.
(‘68 Code, §§ 17-98, 17-99, 17-100) (Ord. passed 8-11-64; Am. Ord. 11-2021-65,
passed 11-9-21)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.129 ISSUANCE OF A PERMIT.
   The issuance of all pier, dock, or boathouse permits will be upon the review
and approval of the City Council.
(‘68 Code, § 17-115) (Ord. passed 8-11-64; Am. Ord. 11-2021-65, passed 11-9-21)
§ 98.130 EXISTING NON-CONFORMING DOCKS, PIERS, AND BOATHOUSES.
   Where a lawful pier, dock, or boathouse exists at the effective date of
adoption or amendment of this subchapter that could not be built under the
terms of this subchapter, such structure may be continued so long as it remains
otherwise lawful, subject to the following provisions:
   (A)   No such non-conforming structure may be enlarged or altered in a way
which increases its non-conformity, but any structure or portion thereof may be
altered to decrease its non-conformity or to comply with city building codes.
   (B)   Should such non-conforming structure or non-conforming portion of a
structure be destroyed by any means to an extent of more than 50% of its
replacement cost at time of destruction; it shall not be reconstructed except
in conformity with the provisions of this subchapter, or when approved by the
City Council.
   (C)   Should such structure be moved any distance for any reason whatsoever,
it shall thereafter conform to the regulations.
(Ord. 11-2021-65, passed 11-9-21)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.131 MAINTENANCE OF PIERS, DOCKS, AND BOATHOUSES.
   All pier, dock, or boathouse structures will be maintained in good repair
and in satisfactory condition so as not to be a nuisance, not to adversely
affect the aesthetic appeal of the lake, not to be detrimental or potentially
detrimental to the water quality, and not to be unsafe for use. Whether a
structure is in good repair and satisfactory condition shall be determined by
the Building Official and/or a city representative. If repairs are required,
the time allowed to make the required repairs to bring the boat dock/lake
access structure into good repair and in satisfactory condition will be
determined by the Building Official and/or a city representative and provided
in writing to the owner.
(Ord. 11-2021-65, passed 11-9-21)
Penalty, see § 98.999
§ 98.132 REMOVAL OF UNPERMITTED PIERS, DOCKS, AND BOATHOUSES.
   Any pier, dock, or boathouse not permitted or maintained or repaired in
accordance with §
98.131, as required by this subchapter shall be removed by the owner within 30
days after the service of written notice by the city to remove same. If such
structure is not removed within the 30-day period, the city may remove, or
cause to be removed, all or any part of the structure at the owner’s expense,
and no further permit shall be issued for any such structure appurtenant to the
property which was served by such removed structure, until the city has been
reimbursed for such removal expense.
(‘68 Code, § 17-117) (Ord. passed 8-11-64; Am. Ord. 11-2021-65, passed 11-9-21)
Penalty, see § 98.999

§ 98.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter for which no
other penalty is set forth shall be subject to the penalty set forth in §
10.99.
   (B)   Violation of §
98.005 is a misdemeanor and upon conviction a person shall be fined an amount
not in excess of $500 for each offense, and each day that a violation is
permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 6-2002-36, passed 6-11-02)
   (C)   Any person, firm, corporation, agent or employee thereof who violates
any of the provisions of §
98.030 through
98.034 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be
fined not to exceed $500 for each offense. Each day that a violation is
permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 10-2000-51, passed 10-10-00; Am. Ord. 08-2010-48, passed 8-10- 10; Am.
Ord. 10-2015-72, passed 10-27-15)
   (D)   Any person convicted of violating §
98.053 by not observing the restricted zone, shall be fined not less than $10
nor more than $100. Should there be a second violation, the fine shall be the
same, with the additional provision that any lake permit held by such person
may be revoked.
('68 Code, § 17-10(c)) (Ord. passed 6-16-67)
   (E)   Any person, firm, corporation, agent, or employee thereof who violates
any of the provisions of §§
98.026,
98.027 or
98.202 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be
fined not to exceed $500 for each offense. Each day that a violation is
permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense.
   (F)   Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits,
neglects or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of §
98.074 shall be fined not less than $5 nor more than $500 for all violations.
Each day that a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense.
   (G)   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits,
neglects, or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of
the provisions of §
98.502 shall be fined not more than $500 for each offense. Each day that a
violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 03-2005-20, passed 3-8-05; Am. Ord. 06-2009-35, passed 6-23-09; Am. Ord.
07-2009-44, passed 7-28-09; Am. Ord. 03-2011-08, passed 3- 22-11; Am. Ord. 04-
2011-19, passed 4-28-11; Am. Ord. 04-2011-20, passed 4-28-11; Am. Ord. 10-2015-
73, passed 10-27-15)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 99.01 CERTAIN ORDINANCES RELATING TO STREETS SAVED FROM REPEAL.
   Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall be deemed to
affect the validity of any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing,
locating-relocating, opening, paving, widening, or vacating any street or
public way in the city, or any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades for
streets or public ways, or any ordinance relating to municipal street
maintenance agreements with the state. Such ordinances are on file in the City
Clerk's office and are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect
to the same extent as if set out at length herein.
('68 Code, § 25-1)
§ 99.02 ADOPTION OF STATE LAW RELATIVE TO STREET IMPROVEMENTS.
   An election held on July, 12, 1924, resulted in the acceptance of the
provisions and benefits and the adoption of chapter 11, title 22, Revised
Statutes of Texas of 1911, relating to street improvements, presently being
Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat., Art. 1086 through 1096, and 1104 and 1105, which shall be
in full force and effect in the city.
('68 Code, § 25-2)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.03 HEARING ON STREET IMPROVEMENT ASSESSMENTS.
   (A)   On the day at the time stated in the notice given pursuant to Tex.
Rev. Civ. Stat., Art. 1093, any person, firm, corporation or association
interested in any property that may be claimed to be subject to assessment for
the purpose of paying the cost of any improvement or any part thereof, made
pursuant to §
99.02, including any railroad or street railroad against the properties of
which and/or the owner of which an assessment is proposed, shall be entitled to
and shall be afforded a full and fair hearing before the City Council as to all
matters offending the property or any claim of personal liability or objection
to any irregularity or invalidity of any of the proceedings with reference to
the making of the improvement, or any other objection thereto, and at such time
such owner shall have the right to contest any assessment proposed to be levied
and any personal liability, the regularity of the proceedings with reference to
the improvement and the benefit of the improvement to his property, and no
assessment shall be made against the owner of any abutting property or against
his property in any event, in excess of the benefit to such owner in the
enhanced value of his property by means of such improvement, as ascertained at
such hearing.
   (B)   At the hearing provided for above, all persons making objections shall
be afforded opportunity to appear in person and/or by representative or
attorney, and produce evidence, and the hearing may be adjourned from time to
time by the City Council until fully completed, and the City Council shall
inquire into and determine all such objections.
('68 Code, § 25-3)
Statutory reference:
   Council to adopt rules providing for hearings to property owners relative to
street improvement assessments, Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat., Art. 1094.
§ 99.04 INTERFERING WITH STREET IMPROVEMENT WORK.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder or obstruct the making or
repairing of any sidewalk, crosswalk or pavement which is being made under
authority of the City Council or to hinder or obstruct any person employed to
make or repair any public improvement ordered by the City Council.
('68 Code, § 25-4)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.05 PROPERTY OWNERS TO MAINTAIN SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be the duty and obligation of all owners, occupants and users of
real property abutting upon streets within the jurisdiction of the city, at
their own cost and expense, to maintain and keep the public sidewalks bordering
their property in a safe and adequate condition, free of vegetation and debris,
so that they are easily accessible to and may be free and safely used by the
public for travel. It shall also be the duty and obligation of all owners,
occupants and users of real property abutting upon streets within the
jurisdiction of the city to repair or replace any portion of public sidewalk
that is damaged or removed by said owners, occupants and users of such real
property.
(‘68 Code, § 25-5) (Am. Ord. 11-2018-96, passed 11-27-18) Penalty, see §
99.99
Cross-reference:
   Liability of city for damages resulting from streets and sidewalks being out
of repair, see Charter §
2.10
§ 99.06 OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, company, or corporation to
obstruct or cause to be obstructed any street, avenue, alley, or sidewalk
within the jurisdiction of the city with vehicles, recreational equipment,
construction equipment, boxes, lumber, timber, firewood, brush, vegetation,
posts, awnings, signs, or other items, substances or materials, in any manner
whatsoever.
   (B)   Upon finding an obstruction prohibited by this section, a police
officer, code enforcement officer, or other employee of the city may remove the
obstruction or cause the obstruction to be removed from the street, avenue,
alley, or sidewalk and dispose of the obstruction.
(‘68 Code, § 25-6) (Am. Ord. 11-2018-96, passed 11-27-18; Am. Ord. 04-2023-30,
passed 4-25-23) Penalty, see §
99.99
Cross-reference:
   Obstruction of crossings by railroads, see §
73.02
§ 99.07 OBSTRUCTION BY TREES, HEDGES OR SHRUBS.
   (A)   Any condition maintained in violation of this section is hereby deemed
a public nuisance, and, in addition to any other remedy or enforcement option
available under the law, the city may pursue the abatement of the condition as
provided under Chapter 96 of this code.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, company, or corporation to
allow a tree, tree limb, or tree branch to be lower than 14 feet above the
surface of any street, avenue, or alley within the jurisdiction of the city.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, company, or corporation to
allow a tree, tree limb, or tree branch to be lower than eight feet above the
surface of any sidewalk within the jurisdiction of the city.
   (D)   Property owners shall maintain a driver's line of sight zone parallel
to the roadway for a horizontal distance of 15 feet from the edge of the
roadway and a vertical clearance that extends from three feet above the surface
of the roadway to eight feet above the curb line. Trees growing in the driver's
line of sight zone shall be at least ten feet from other trees in the driver's
line of sight zone.
   (E)   Property owners shall maintain a driver's line of sight zone at all
corners of street-to-street intersections. The driver's line of sight zone
shall be in the shape of a horizontal triangle created by measuring 25 feet
from the intersection in perpendicular directions along the curb line or edge
of the roadway. The driver's line of sight zone shall have a vertical clearance
that extends from three feet above the surface of the roadway to eight feet
above the curb line.
(‘68 Code, § 25-7) (Am. Ord. 02-2012-04, passed 2-14-12; Am. Ord. 11-2018-96,
passed 11-27-18) Penalty, see §
99.99
§ 99.08 DISPLAY OF GOODS, WARES AND MERCHANDISE ON SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be unlawful for any merchant, trader, broker, or other person to
use more than one-third of any sidewalk within the jurisdiction of the city for
the display of goods, wares, or merchandise, provided such merchant, trader,
broker, or other person shall remove all merchandise from such sidewalk each
night.
(‘68 Code, § 25-8) (Am. Ord. passed 7-13-71; Am. Ord. 11-2018-96, passed 11-27-
18) Penalty, see §
99.99
§ 99.09 AWNINGS OVER SIDEWALKS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, company, or corporation to
suspend or put up any awning within the jurisdiction of the city:
      (1)    Less than seven feet above any sidewalk; or
      (2)   Within 18 inches of the any curb line.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, company, or corporation to
hang any sign on an awning that hangs below the lowest fixed portion of the
awning.
(‘68 Code, § 25-9) (Ord. passed 3-15-55; Am. Ord. passed 4-12-55; Am. Ord. 11-
2018-96, passed 11-27-18) Penalty, see §
99.99
§ 99.10 DUMPING OR SPILLING OF LOADS PROHIBITED; REMEDIES; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any person,
willfully or negligently, to dump, deposit, leak, drip, spill or throw, or to
cause or permit the dumping, depositing, leaking, dropping, spilling or
throwing, of any sand, gravel, concrete, water or any other fluid, dirt, mud,
rock, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans or any other substance, in or upon any
part or portion of any street, highway, alley or other public thoroughfare, or
in or upon any part or portion of any private road or driveway, within the
corporate limits of the city, from any part or portion of any motor or other
vehicle in or upon any part or portion of such thoroughfare or way, in any
quantity sufficient to constitute a hazard or imminent danger to the safety or
health of persons or vehicles using any part or portion of any such
thoroughfare or way, or to be injurious or detrimental to any part or portion
of any such thoroughfare or way.
   (B)   Where any person has violated the provisions of this section by
unlawfully dumping, depositing, leaking, dropping, spilling or throwing or by
unlawfully causing or permitting the dumping, depositing, leaking, dropping,
spilling or throwing of any such sand, gravel, concrete, water or any other
fluid, dirt, mud, rock, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans or other substance in
or upon any part or portion of any such street, highway, alley or public
thoroughfare, or in or upon any part of portion of any such private road or
driveway, the owner or lessee of any such vehicle from which the same was so
dumped, deposited, leaked, dropped, spilled or thrown shall forthwith collect
and remove the same from any such street, highway, alley or other thoroughfare,
or private road or driveway, upon learning of the presence and location of
same, and it shall be unlawful for the owner or lessee of the vehicle from
which the same was dumped, deposited, leaked, dropped, spilled or thrown to
fail or refuse to collect and remove the same forthwith upon actual notice of
the presence and location of same given to any such owner or lessee by any
officer or employee of the city.
   (C)   The provisions set forth and contained in divisions (A) and (B) of
this section shall have no application to the dumping, depositing or pouring of
any substance or material necessary and essential to the construction or repair
of any part or portion of any such thoroughfare, or any structure or facility
thereon, at the site thereof.
   (D)   As used herein, the words “motor vehicle,” “street,” “highway,”
“private road,” “private driveway” shall have the definitions and meanings
prescribed for them as contained and set forth in Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat., Art.
6701d. [See also §
70.01 of this code of ordinances.]
('68 Code, § 25-10) (Ord. 12-1974-47, passed 12-10-74)
Penalty, see § 99.99
CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR OF SIDEWALKS, DRIVEWAYS AND THE LIKE
§ 99.20 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COMMERCIAL DRIVEWAY. Any driveway into a place of business which serves or
is served by automobile traffic, including (but without limitation) filling
stations and warehouses, shall be classified as a commercial driveway.
   CONTRACTOR. The person, partnership, corporation or other entity, which
undertakes or contracts to construct driveways, sidewalks, curbs and gutters,
paving, and setbacks in city streets and alleys.
   OWNER. The property owner, individual or firm, having the work done by the
contractor.
   SETBACK. That additional area formed by setting the curb back from the
regular curb alignment towards the property line to obtain a more convenient
parking space in the street abutting a commercial establishment. In no case
shall a setback be constructed where the additional depth obtained is less than
eight feet.
('68 Code, § 25-20) (Ord. passed 4-12-55)
§ 99.21 PURPOSE.
   It is the intent and purpose of this subchapter to protect the public safety
and general welfare by setting up a standard of quality and workmanship in the
construction and repair of curbs and gutters, sidewalks, driveways, paving and
setbacks in city streets, alleys and public ways.
('68 Code, § 25-21) (Ord. passed 4-12-55)
§ 99.22 APPLICATION.
   This subchapter shall apply to the construction and repair of curbs and
gutters, sidewalks, driveways and setbacks in city streets and alleys, and
shall not apply to such construction or repair on private property.
('68 Code, § 25-22) (Ord. passed 4-12-55)
§ 99.23 PERMIT.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, reconstruct or
repair any sidewalk, setback, driveway, curb, gutter, or work incident
thereto,in the streets and alleys of the city without first obtaining a permit
for such work from the Public Works Department. Applications for such permits
shall be made on forms furnished by the city. A permit fee of $15 shall be paid
by the applicant at the time application is made.
   (B)   No permit issued under this section shall be assigned, transferred or
sublet. The permittee shall remain in personal charge of all work done
thereunder.
   (C)   A permit issued to any contractor who shall sublet, transfer or assign
his contract or permit any other to have control of such work is subject to
immediate revocation and the Director of Public Works or his designee is hereby
authorized to order that all work issued under such permit immediately cease.
('68 Code, § 25-23) (Ord. passed 4-12-55; Am. Ord. 6-1993-21, passed 6-24-93)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.24 CONSTRUCTION AND RECONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS.
   All driveway construction and reconstruction shall comply with “City of
Cleburne Driveway Standards” and the “Standard Driveway Detail” contained in §
154.088.
('68 Code, § 25-24) (Ord. passed 4-12-55; Am. Ord. 6-1993-21, passed 6-24-93)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.25 SPECIAL PERMISSION FOR INSTALLATION OF SETBACK.
   A setback may be installed only by special permission of the City Engineer.
Request for such permission shall be made by the owner in writing, accompanied
by a sketch indicating the work to be done.
('68 Code, § 25-25) (Ord. passed 4-12-55)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.26 CONTRACTOR'S BOND.
   The contractor desiring to construct any of the improvements covered by this
subchapter shall execute a bond in the sum of $2,000, which bond shall be a
surety company bond made payable to the Mayor and his successor in office, to
be approved by the Mayor and filed with the City Secretary, conditioned that
the principal in the bond shall faithfully comply with all the requirements of
the ordinances of the city regulating the building of sidewalks, curb and
gutter, steps, or driveways and will repair, free of cost, any sidewalk,
curbing, gutter, steps or driveways built by such person that may become
defective, within one year from the date of completion, due to defective
workmanship or materials. Contractor shall repair all damages to public
infrastructure including streets, traffic signal loops, storm drainage, water
and sewer lines, etc. that may be damaged during construction of improvements
covered by this subchapter and will within one year from date of repair, repair
free of charge areas that may become defective due to materials or workmanship.
('68 Code, § 25-26) (Ord. passed 4-12-55; Am. Ord. 05-2009-29, passed 5-26-09)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.27 LINES AND GRADES.
   The City Engineer shall furnish information and set stakes establishing
lines and grades for the construction, reconstruction or repair of any
improvement covered by this subchapter, within four working days after a permit
has been granted for such construction, and all such construction shall be in
accord with such lines and grades.
('68 Code, § 25-27) (Ord. passed 4-12-55)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.28 SPECIFICATIONS.
   All work performed under a permit issued pursuant to this subchapter, and
all materials used therein, shall comply with the specifications therefor set
out in section 10 of the ordinance, upon which this subchapter is based,
adopted by the City Council on April 12, 1955, a copy of which is on file in
the City Clerk's office. No deviation from such specifications shall be made
without written authority from the City Engineer.
('68 Code, § 25-28) (Ord. passed 4-12-55)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.29 OCCUPANCY OF STREET WITH MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT; BARRICADES.
   No more than one-third of the width of the street shall be occupied by
materials, equipment or tools used in the construction or repair of any
improvement subject to the provisions of this subchapter, and barricades shall
be placed around such equipment so as to leave at least two-thirds of such
street open for traffic. Such barricades and street obstructions shall be
supplied with lights at night so that the same will serve as protection to the
public.
('68 Code, § 25-29) (Ord. passed 4-12-55)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.30 APPROVAL OF WORK.
   All work and construction performed pursuant to a permit issued under this
subchapter shall be subject to the approval of the City Engineer.
('68 Code, § 25-30) (Ord. passed 4-12-55)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.31 MAINTENANCE OF SETBACK AREA.
   The property owner shall be required to maintain a setback area constructed
under this subchapter in a clean, presentable condition at his own expense. In
case the setback area is not maintained properly, the owner may be required by
the City Council to remove the setback within a reasonable length of time and
replace it with a standard curb and gutter and, where necessary, a sidewalk,
all at his own expense.
('68 Code, § 25-31) (Ord. passed 4-12-55)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.32 REPLACEMENT OF OBSOLETE SETBACKS.
   In case a setback, due to development of the abutting property, has become
obsolete and of no further use to the property, the owner may be required by
the City Council to remove such setback and replace it with a standard curb and
gutter and where necessary, a sidewalk, all at his own expense.
('68 Code, § 25-32) (Ord. passed 4-12-55)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.33 REPLACEMENT OF OBSOLETE DRIVEWAYS.
   In case a driveway, due to development of the abutting property, has become
obsolete and of no further use to the property, the owner may be required by
the City Council to remove such driveway and replace it with a standard curb
and gutter and, where necessary, a sidewalk, all at his own expense.
