STREET EXCAVATIONS
§ 99.40 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS. The person employed by the city as such and
appointed by the City Manager.
   EXCAVATION. The making of a hole or cavity of any size in a surface, the
boring or tunnelling under a surface or the disruption or breaking of a
surface.
   PERSON. Any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
company, business entity or organization of any kind. This term shall not
include the city.
   STREET. The surface of and the space above and below any public street,
road, highway, freeway, lane, path, public way, ground or place, sidewalk,
alley, boulevard, parkway, drive, street right-of-way or easement now or
hereafter held by the city for a public purpose.
('68 Code, § 25-44) (Ord. 5-1979-25, passed 5-8-79)
Cross-reference:
   Protection of street excavations made during construction work, see §
150.003
§ 99.41 BORING AND TUNNELLING.
   When an excavation is planned to be made in an improved street, such
excavation shall be accomplished only by boring or tunnelling under such street
where feasible or practicable. The Director of Public Works shall make the
determination of feasibility or practicality before a permit is issued.
('68 Code, § 25-45) (Ord. 5-1979-26, passed 5-8-79)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.42 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person shall make an excavation in or under a street without first
obtaining an effective and valid permit to do so from the Director of Public
Works or his designated representative.
   (B)   Any person desiring a permit shall apply for such at least 24 hours
before the commencement of any work. A permit is not effective and valid until
it is signed by the Director of Public Works or his designated representative.
   (C)   The work for which a permit is issued shall be commenced within 30
days of the effective date of the permit. In the event that special,
exceptional or unusual circumstances prevent the commencement of the work
within the initial 30-day period, the holder of the permit may apply for a time
extension before the expiration of the initial time period, and the Director of
Public Works may approve the same; provided, that no time extension shall
exceed 30 days. If such work is not commenced with the initial time period or
any extension thereof, the permit shall be null and void.
   (D)   Any person making an excavation in or under a street without an
effective and valid permit shall cease all excavation work when ordered to do
so by the Director of Public Works or his designated representative and shall
not resume such work until he has complied with this subchapter.
   (E)   Division (A) of this section shall not apply to emergency situations
where excavations are needed immediately to correct or remove a situation which
presents an immediate and imminent threat to the health, safety and welfare of
the public. However, in these situations, the person making the excavation
shall apply for and obtain an effective and valid permit from the designated
official on the next working day.
   (F)   Division (A) shall not apply to the following excavations made in that
portion of a street between the right-of-way line and curb or edge of an
improved roadway:
      (1)   Excavations made by a resident or owner of the abutting property or
a holder of some other valid type of permit issued by the city;
      (2)   Excavations made for the placement of utility poles and guy anchors
by a utility company which is operating under a franchise agreement with the
city; and
      (3)   Excavations made for the installation of utility service drops
where the trench is attended at all times by utility company employees, and the
trench is not in existence for more than one hour.
   (G)   The exceptions mentioned in this subsection apply only to permit
requirements and do not exclude any person from the other requirements
established by this subchapter. Excavations for tunnelling or boring shall
require a permit.
('68 Code, § 25-45.1) (Ord. 5-1979-25, passed 5-8-79)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.43 PERMIT FEES.
   (A)   The following fees shall be paid for permits required by §
99.42:
      (1)   For excavations in and under unpaved streets, the permit fee shall
be $3.
      (2)   For excavations in and under paved streets, the permit fee shall be
$5.
   (B)   Any utility company which pays a franchise fee to the city shall not
be required to pay a permit fee.
('68 Code, § 25-46) (Ord. 5-1979-25, passed 5-8-79)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.44 RESTORING THE SURFACE.
   (A)   When an excavation is made in or under any street, the person doing
such work shall restore the street within a reasonable length of time after the
completion of the work to as good a condition as before the commencement of the
work and according to the specifications established by the director of public
works. Any length of time in excess of three days shall be prima facie evidence
that the length of time is not reasonable. In the event that special or unusual
circumstances prevent the restoration of the surface of a street within a
reasonable length of time, the person who made the excavation shall obtain the
Director of Public Works' approval for a time extension and shall maintain the
excavation in a safe and easily traversable condition until the surface is
restored.
   (B)   Any person who has restored or caused to be restored any street
pursuant to this subchapter shall maintain to the satisfaction of the Director
of Public Works for one year the surface of the street.
   (C)   If a person who has made an excavation in or under a street fails to
restore said street within a reasonable length of time and has not obtained a
time extension, or fails to restore said street according to the specifications
prescribed herein, or fails to maintain the street for the length of time
prescribed herein, the Director of Public Works shall notify the person in
writing to properly restore or maintain the street within five days after such
notice. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with such notice.
   (D)   If a person fails to comply with the notice provided for in division
(C), the Director of Public Works may cause the street to be properly restored
or maintained and shall charge said person with the cost of such work. It shall
be unlawful for any person who has failed to comply with said notice to fail to
pay these costs.
   (E)   If the city restores or maintains a street because of the failure of a
person to comply with the requirements of this section, the person shall be
charged with the cost incurred by the city for such work. The Director of
Public Works shall establish a rate schedule for labor, equipment and materials
and shall update the same from time to time. The city's cost shall be computed
according to such schedule.
   (F)   When a person makes or causes to be made an excavation in a street,
the person shall place, erect and maintain an adequate number of warning
devices around said excavation to protect the public until the street is
restored. The type and number of warning devices and the placement of the same
shall conform to the latest edition of the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic
Control Devices. No person shall encumber a street for a longer period of time
than shall be reasonably necessary to execute the work. Any length of time in
excess of 30 days shall be prima facie evidence that the length of time is not
reasonable. The Director of Public Works may issue an extension of time only in
special or unusual situations.
   (G)   A person who makes an excavation in an area behind a curb but within a
street right-of-way shall comply with all the requirements, time limits and
guidelines established for excavations in and under streets.
('68 Code, § 25-47) (Ord. 5-1979-25, passed 5-8-79)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.45 MINIMUM DEPTH OF UTILITY PIPES BELOW CITY-OWNED PROPERTY.
   If any person shall place or cause to be placed in any street, alley, public
square or market square, or any park, or on any lot of whatever kind or
character or description which is owned or controlled by the city, any pipes
for the transmission of water, gas, sewerage or electrical current, at a less
depth than 18 inches below the grade level of the street, gutter, lot, alley,
park car square, at the time of laying such pipe, the city shall in no way be
liable or responsible for the displacement or breakage, or for disturbing in
any way whatsoever, the pipes so laid, and the city shall be held free from
indemnity, damage or legal proceedings of any character whatever by reasons of
the failure on the part of such person to lay such pipes to such depth as above
designated.
('68 Code, § 19-7)
Penalty, see § 99.99
§ 99.99 PENALTY.
   It is an offense for a person, firm, company, or corporation to violate,
disobey, omit, neglect, or refuse to comply with or resist the enforcement of
any of the provisions of this chapter. Each day that a violation is permitted
to exist shall constitute a separate offense. An offense under this section is
a Class C misdemeanor. Any offense for which no other penalty is set forth in
this chapter shall be subject to the penalty set forth in §
10.99 of this code.
(‘68 Code, § 25-48) (Ord. 5-1979-25, passed 5-8-79; Am. Ord. 5-1979-26, passed
5-8-79; Am. Ord. 7-1991-21, passed 7-25-91; Am. Ord. 11-2018-96, passed 11-27-
18)
CHAPTER 100: FAIR HOUSING
Section
   
100.01   Definitions
   
100.02   Discrimination in the sale or rental of housing
   
100.03   Discrimination in the financing of housing
   
100.04   Discrimination in the provision of brokerage services
   
100.05   Exemptions and exclusions
   
100.06   Fair Housing Administrator
   
100.07   Complaints
   
100.08   Investigation
   
100.09   Legal proceedings
   
100.10   Cooperation with Secretary of Housing and Urban Development
   
100.11   Unlawful intimidation
   
100.12   Education and public information
 
   
100.99   Penalty
§ 100.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DISCRIMINATORY HOUSING PRACTICE. An act that is unlawful under §§
100.02 through
100.04.
   DWELLING. Any building, structure or portion thereof which is occupied as,
or designed and intended for occupancy as, a residence by one or more families
or any vacant land which is offered for sale or lease for the construction of
location thereon of any such building, structure or portion thereof.
   FAMILY. A single individual.
   PERSON. One or more individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations,
labor organizations, legal representatives, mutual companies, joint stock
companies, trusts, unincorporated organizations, trustees, fiduciaries, and any
other organization or entity of whatever character.
   TO RENT. To lease, to sublease, to let and otherwise to grant for a
consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant.
('68 Code, § 11½-1) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79)
§ 100.02 DISCRIMINATION IN THE SALE OR RENTAL OF HOUSING.
   Except as exempted by section §
100.05, it shall be unlawful:
   (A)   To refuse to sell or rent, after the making of a bona fide offer, or
to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make unavailable
or deny, a dwelling to any person because of race, color, sex, handicap,
familial status, religion or national origin;
   (B)   To discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or
privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or
facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color, sex, handicap,
familial status, religion or national origin;
   (C)   To make, print, publish or cause to be made, printed or published any
notice, statement or advertisement regarding the sale or rental of a dwelling
that indicates any preference, limitation or discrimination based on race,
color, sex, handicap, familial status, religion or national origin, or an
intention to make any such preference, limitation or discrimination;
   (D)   To represent to any person because of race, color, sex, handicap,
familial status, religion or national origin that any dwelling is not available
for inspection, sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact so available;
   (E)   For profit or with the hope or expectation of profit, to induce or to
attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations
regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person or
persons of a particular race, color, sex, handicap, familial status, religion
or national origin;
   (F)   For profit or with the hope or expectation of profit, to influence or
to attempt to influence, by any words, acts or failure to act, any seller,
purchaser, landlord or tenant of a dwelling so as to promote the maintenance of
racially segregated housing or so as to retard, obstruct or discourage racially
integrated housing.
('68 Code, § 11½-2) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79; Am. Ord. 9-1995-34, passed
9-26-95)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.03 DISCRIMINATION IN THE FINANCING OF HOUSING.
   It shall be unlawful for any bank, building and loan association, insurance
company or other corporation, association, firm or enterprise whose business
consists in whole or in part in the making of commercial real estate loans to
deny a loan or other financial assistance to a person applying therefor for the
purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a
dwelling, or to discriminate against him in the fixing of the amount, interest
rate, duration or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial
assistance because of the race, color, sex, handicap, familial status, religion
or national origin of such person or of any person associated with him in
connection with such loan or other financial assistance or the purpose of such
loan or other financial assistance, or of the present or prospective owners,
lessees, tenants or occupants of the dwelling or dwellings in relation to which
such loan or other financial assistance is to be made or given.
('68 Code, § 11½-3) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79; Am. Ord. 9-1995-34, passed
9-26-95)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.04 DISCRIMINATION IN THE PROVISION OF BROKERAGE SERVICES. 
   It shall be unlawful for any person to deny access to, or membership or
participation in, any multiple listing service, real estate brokers'
organization or other service, organization or facility relating to the
business of selling or renting dwellings, or to discriminate in the terms or
conditions of such access, membership or participation, on account of race,
color, sex, handicap, familial status, religion or national origin.
('68 Code, § 11½-4) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79; Am. Ord. 9-1995-34, passed
9-26-95)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.05 EXEMPTIONS AND EXCLUSIONS.
   (A)   There shall be exempted from the application of section § 100.02
hereof all transactions involving:
      (1)   The rental of units in dwellings containing living quarters
occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four families living
independently of each other if the owner actually maintains and occupies one of
such units as his residence;
      (2)   The rental of a single room in a dwelling containing living
quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than one family if the
person offering such room for rental actually maintains and occupies the
remainder of such dwelling as his residence and not more than four such rooms
are offered.
      (3)   (a)   The sale or rental of any single house by a private
individual who owns such house, provided that:
            1.   The sale or rental is made without the use in any manner of
the sales or rental facilities or the sales or rental services of any real
estate broker, agent or salesman, or of such facilities or services of any
person in the business of selling or renting dwellings or of any employee or
agent of any such broker, agent, salesman or person; and
            2.   The sale is made without the publication, posting or mailing
of any advertisement or written notice in violation of §
100.02(C) of this chapter (this shall not prohibit the use of attorneys, escrow
agents, abstracters, title companies and other such professional assistance as
necessary to perfect or transfer the title); and
            3.   The owner does not own more than three single-family houses at
the time of the sale; and
            4.   The owner does not own any interest in, nor is there owned or
reserved on his behalf, under any express or voluntary agreement, title to or
any right to all or any portion of the proceeds from the sale or rental of,
more than three such single-family houses at any one time.
         (b)   If the owner does not reside in the house at the time of sale or
was not the most recent resident of such house prior to the sale, the exemption
granted by this subsection shall apply only with respect to one such sale
within any 24-month period.
   (B)   Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit a religious organization,
association or society or any nonprofit institution or organization operated,
supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization,
association or society from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings
which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the
same religion, or from giving preference to such persons, unless membership in
such religion is restricted on account of race, color, sex handicap, familial
status or national origin.
   (C)   Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit a bona fide private club, not
in fact open to the public, which, as an incident to its primary purpose,
provides lodging which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose,
from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodging to its members or from
giving preference to its members.
   (D)   Nothing in this chapter shall bar any person from owning and operating
a housing accommodation in which a room or rooms are leased, subleased or
rented only to persons of the same sex, when such housing accommodation
contains common lavatory, kitchen or similar facilities available for the use
of all persons occupying such housing accommodation.
('68 Code, § 11½-5) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79; Am. Ord. 9-1995-34, passed
9-26-95)
§ 100.06 FAIR HOUSING ADMINISTRATOR.
   The City Manager shall appoint a qualified city employee to serve as the
Fair Housing Administrator (hereinafter referred to as “Administrator”), who
shall have the responsibility for implementing this chapter.
('68 Code, § 11½-6) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79)
§ 100.07 COMPLAINTS.
   (A)   Any credible person who claims to have been injured by a
discriminatory housing practice or who believes that he will be irrevocably
injured by a discriminatory housing practice that is about to occur (hereafter
referred to a “person aggrieved”) may file a complaint with the Administrator.
Such complaints shall be in writing and shall identify the person alleged to
have committed or alleged to be about to commit the discriminatory housing
practice and shall set forth the particulars thereof. The Administrator is
directed to prepare and adopt from time to time standard complaint forms and to
furnish them without charge to any person aggrieved.
   (B)   The Administrator shall receive and accept notification and referral
of complaints from the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development pursuant to
the provisions of Title VIII, Fair Housing Act of 1988, being 42 USC 3601 et
seq., and shall treat such complaints in the same manner as complaints filed
directly by the person aggrieved.
   (C)   If, in the course of any investigation as provided in §
100.08 on a complaint filed with or referred to the Administrator, he shall
receive credible evidence and shall have probable cause to believe that the
person or persons named in such complaint have committed a discriminatory
housing practice on grounds not stated in such complaint, the administrator may
prepare and file a supplementary complaint upon his own motion and in his own
name; and such supplementary complaint thereafter be treated in the same manner
as an original complaint filed by a person aggrieved.
   (D)   Upon the filing or referral of any complaint, the administrator shall
furnish a copy of the same to the person or persons named in the complaint.
   (E)   All complaints filed under divisions (A), (B) and (C) shall be filed
within 60 days after the alleged discriminatory housing practice occurred.
Complaints shall state the facts upon which the allegations of a discriminatory
housing practice are based. The accused may file an answer to the complaint
against him within 15 days of his receipt of the complaint and, with the leave
of the Administrator, which shall be granted whenever it would be reasonable
and fair to do so, may amend his answer at any time. A copy of an amendment to
a complaint or an answer shall be furnished to the opposing party. Both
complaints and answers shall be signed by the persons making them and sworn to
before an officer authorized to administer oaths.
('68 Code, § 11½-7) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79; Am. Ord. 9-1995-34, passed
9-26-95)
§ 100.08 INVESTIGATION.
   (A)   Upon the filing of a complaint as herein provided, the administrator
shall cause to be made a prompt investigation of the matter stated in the
complaint.
   (B)   In connection with such investigation, the Administrator may question
and take and record testimony and statements of persons and may examine, record
and copy documents.
   (C)   During or after the investigation, the administrator shall, if it
appears that a discriminatory housing practice act has occurred or is about to
occur, attempt by informal endeavors to effect conciliation, including
voluntary discontinuance or rectification of the discriminatory housing
practice and voluntary compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
   (D)   In the event conciliation is effected, the Administrator shall
disclose nothing said or done in the course of such conciliation in such a way
as to make public identification of the person or persons named in the
complaint without written consent of the persons concerned.
   (E)   Upon completion of the investigation and informal endeavors at
conciliation by the administrator, but within 30 days of the filing of the
complaint with the Administrator, if the efforts of the Administrator to secure
voluntary compliance have been unsuccessful, and if the Administrator has made
a determination that a discriminatory housing practice has in fact occurred,
the Administrator shall recommend to the City Attorney that such violation be
prosecuted in municipal court. If the City Attorney determines to prosecute, he
shall file a formal complaint in municipal court and prosecute same to
conclusion within 30 days after such filing or as soon thereafter as
practicable.
('68 Code, § 11½-8) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79)
§ 100.09 LEGAL PROCEEDINGS.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as an administrative prerequisite
to a citizen pursuing his rights under any other federal, state or local
statute, case decision or administrative ruling..This chapter is cumulative in
its legal effect and is not in lieu of any and all other legal remedies which a
citizen may pursue.
('68 Code, § 11½-9) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79)
§ 100.10 COOPERATION WITH SECRETARY OF HOUSING AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT.
   The Administrator and the City Attorney are authorized and encouraged to
cooperate with the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, pursuant to the
provisions of Title VIII, Fair Housing Act of 1988, being 42 USC 3601 et seq.,
and may render such service to the Secretary as they shall deem appropriate to
further the policies of this chapter and may accept reimbursement from the
Secretary for services rendered to assist him in carrying out the provisions of
the above-cited federal law.
('68 Code, § 11½-10) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79; Am. Ord. 9-1995-34, passed
9-26-95)
§ 100.11 UNLAWFUL INTIMIDATION.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, whether or not acting under color
of law, by force of that of force to willfully injure, intimidate or interfere,
or attempt to injure, intimidate or interfere with:
      (1)   Any person because of his race, color, sex, religion or national
origin and because he is or has been selling, purchasing, renting, financing,
occupying, or contracting or negotiating for the sale, purchase, rental,
financing or occupation of any dwelling, or applying for or participating in
any service, organization or facility relating to the business of selling or
renting dwellings; or
      (2)   Any person because he is or has been, or in order to intimidate
such person or any other person or class of persons from:
         (a)   Participating, without discrimination on account of race, color,
sex, religion or national origin, in any of the activities, services,
organizations or facilities described in division (1) above; or
         (b)   Affording another person or class of persona opportunity or
protection so to participate; or
      (3)   Any person because he is or has been or in order to discourage such
person or any other person from lawfully aiding or encouraging other persons to
participate, without discrimination on account of race, color, sex, religion or
national origin, in any of the activities, services, organizations or
facilities described in division (1) above or participating lawfully in speech
or peaceable assembly opposing any denial of the opportunity so to participate.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to harass, threaten, harm, damage
or otherwise penalize any individual, group or business because he or they have
complied with the provisions of this chapter, or enjoyed the benefits of this
chapter, or because he or they have made a charge, testified or assisted in any
manner in any investigation or in any proceeding hereunder, or have made any
report to the administrator.
('68 Code, § 11½-11) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79)
Penalty, see § 100.99
§ 100.12 EDUCATION AND PUBLIC INFORMATION.
   In order to further the objectives of this chapter, the Administrator may
conduct educational and public information programs.
('68 Code, § 11½-12) (Ord. 2-1979-5, passed 2-13-79)
§ 100.99 PENALTY.
   Violation of the provisions of this chapter is punishable by a fine not to
exceed $500 per day per violation thereof as provided in §
10.99.

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 101.001 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein:
   AMPLIFIED SOUND. Any sound projected or transmitted by artificial means,
including but not limited to, amplifiers, loudspeakers or any other similar
devices.
   CITY. The City of Cleburne, Texas.
   CLEBURNE CONFERENCE CENTER MANAGER. That individual charged with the
responsibilities of overseeing the maintenance, care and scheduling of events
of the Cleburne Conference Center.
   CONFERENCE CENTER MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT. Management agreement assigns
administration, reservations, and day-to-day operations of the conference
center to an organization approved by Council. This agreement is administered
by the City Manager or his designee.
   DEPARTMENT. The Conference Center department.
   DIRECTOR. The Community Services Director.
   PARKING AREA. Any designated portion of land surrounding the Cleburne
Conference Center or senior citizens center.
   PERSON. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
   RESERVATION. An executed contract from the Cleburne Conference Center
manager gaining permission to carry out a given activity on a specific date in
a specific facility.
   SENIOR CITIZENS ADVISORY BOARD SPONSORED ACTIVITY. Any activity, held at the
Senior Citizens Center, sponsored by the Senior Citizens Advisory Board.
   SENIOR CITIZENS CENTER. The structure designated for senior citizen
activities.
   VEHICLE. Any wheeled device of conveyance, propelled by motor or engine. The
term shall include any trailer of any kind, size or description. Exception is
made for any city-owned vehicle.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2000-31, passed 4-25- 00; Am.
Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12; Am. Ord. 03-2018-24, passed 3-27-18)
§ 101.002 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to establish rules and regulations for the
Cleburne Conference Center and the senior citizens center facilities of the
City of Cleburne, designed for the use and enjoyment of the citizens of the
city.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)
§ 101.003 MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL.
   The Cleburne Conference Center and the senior citizens center including all
equipment located therein shall be under the management and control of the City
Manager or his appointed Community Services Director or designee who shall be
responsible to the City Manager in the conduct and affairs of these facilities.
Care and control responsibilities of overseeing the maintenance, care and
scheduling of events of the Senior Citizens Center is under the direction of
the Community Services Director.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12; Am.
Ord. 03-2018-24, passed 3-27-18)
§ 101.004 CLEBURNE CONFERENCE CENTER DEPARTMENT CREATED.
   There shall be a department of city government to be known as the Cleburne
Conference Center Department. This department shall consist of the Cleburne
Conference Center. This department shall be under the immediate supervision of
the Cleburne Conference Center Manager or the City Manager’s designee. This
department shall be a part of the City Manager’s Administration and as such is
under the supervision and control of the City Manager or his designee.
Community Services Director has oversight of the Senior Citizens Center and its
operations.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12; Am.
Ord. 03-2018-24, passed 3-27-18)
§ 101.005 DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR.
   Subject to the approval of the City Manager, the Community Services Director
or the City Manager's designee shall be responsible for determining overall
policies, regulations and programs governing acquisition, improvement,
maintenance and operation of the Cleburne Conference Center and the senior
citizens center. The Director or the City Manager's designee shall be
responsible to the City Manager for administration and implementation of the
policies established by the City Manager and/or City Council in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12; Am.
Ord. 03-2018-24, passed 3-27-18)
§ 101.006 DUTIES OF THE CLEBURNE CONFERENCE CENTER MANAGER AND COMMUNITY
SERVICES DIRECTOR.
    Subject to the approval of the City Manager and Council, the management
agreement will direct, the Cleburne Conference Center Manager to be responsible
for the day-to-day operations of the Cleburne Conference Center. This shall
include the maintenance and care of these facilities as well as the scheduling
of events to be held in each facility. This agreement shall be administered by
the City Manager or his designee. The Community Services Director will be
responsible for the day-to-day operations of the Senior Citizens Center. This
shall include the maintenance and care of this facility as well as the
scheduling of events to be held in the facility.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12; Am.
Ord. 03-2018-24, passed 3-27-18)
§ 101.007 APPOINTMENT OF EMPLOYEES.
   The management agreement includes hiring and overseeing the Conference
Center Manager and support staff. The agreement includes administration of
payroll and insurance of facility personnel.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12; Am.
Ord. 03-2018-24, passed 3-27-18)
§ 101.008 JURISDICTION.
   The rules and regulations of this chapter shall be in force in the Cleburne
Conference Center and the senior citizens center unless specifically exempted
by this article.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)
§ 101.009 CONDITIONS FOR USE; ENFORCEMENT.
   Compliance with the rules and regulations of this chapter is a condition of
the use of the Cleburne Conference Center and the senior citizens center.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)
§ 101.010 FIREARMS; DISCHARGE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any gun, pistol, air gun or
firearm of any kind in the facilities or on the grounds of the Cleburne
Conference Center and the senior citizens center.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)
CLEBURNE CONFERENCE CENTER; SENIOR CITIZENS CENTER PROPERTIES
§ 101.030 BUILDINGS AND OTHER PROPERTY.
   No person shall do, or cause to be done, any of the following, inside or
outside of the Cleburne Conference Center or the senior citizens center,
without first obtaining a permit:
   (A)   Mark, deface, injure, displace, remove or tamper with any piece of
equipment, furniture, fixtures, buildings or other property of said facilities.
   (B)   Construct, alter, modify or erect any partition or structure of any
kind, whether permanently or temporarily, without written consent from the
Community Services Division Director.
(Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)
§ 101.031 MERCHANDISING, ADVERTISING AND SIGNS.
   No person, within the said facilities or on the grounds of the facilities
shall:
   (A)   Expose or offer for sale or hire any article, thing or service, nor
station or place any stand, cart or vehicle for the transportation, sale or
display of any article, thing or service unless a permit has been obtained from
the Cleburne Conference Center Manager.
   (B)   Announce, advertise or call the public's attention in any way to any
article, thing or service for sale or hire unless done pursuant to a permit
obtained from the Cleburne Conference Center Manager.
   (C)   Paste, glue, tack or otherwise place any sign, placard, advertisement
or inscription on any facility of this department or cause to be erected any
sign on any property owned by the city surrounding said facilities unless done
pursuant to a permit obtained from the Cleburne Conference Center Manager.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)
§ 101.032 INTERFERENCE WITH USERS OR PERMITTEES.
   No person shall prevent, disturb or unreasonably interfere with any person
or group occupying any area or room or participating in any lawful activity
permitted within the Cleburne Conference Center and the senior citizens center
or on surrounding public property of these facilities.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)
RESERVATION PROCEDURES
§ 101.040 RESERVATIONS REQUIRED.
   In addition to any other provision of this chapter that requires the
obtaining of a reservation prior to engaging in a given activity, no person
shall conduct, operate, present, manage or take part in any of the following
activities in the Cleburne Conference Center and the senior citizens center
unless a reservation is obtained prior to the start of such activity:
   (A)   Any organized event using all or a portion of said facilities.
   (B)   Any exhibit, dramatic performance, play, motion picture, radio or
television broadcast, fair, musical event or any similar event.
   (C)   Any public meeting, assembly, ceremony, address, speech, political
meeting or other gathering.
   (D)   Any organized sports activity.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)
§ 101.041 RESERVATION PROCEDURE.
   (A)   An executed reservation contract is required to guarantee a
reservation.
   (B)   Only persons twenty-one (21) years of age or older can reserve the
Cleburne Conference Center or the senior citizens center.
   (C)   The rental period is outlined in the Fee Schedule Section. Extended
hours for cleanup may be arranged in advance with the Cleburne Conference
Center Manager, if the facility is available during the time requested.
   (D)   A person seeking issuance of a reservation to conduct an activity or
event in these facilities shall file an application with the Cleburne
Conference Center Manager. The application shall state:
      (1)   The name, mailing address and telephone number of the person and/or
organization and its officers applying for the permit.
      (2)   If the use or activity is to be conducted for, on behalf of or by
any person other than the applicant, then state their name, mailing address and
telephone number.
      (3)   The exact nature of the use, event or activity for which the
reservation is being sought.
      (4)   The day and hours for which the reservation is desired.
      (5)   The room or recreational area desired to be reserved.
      (6)   An estimate of the anticipated attendance.
      (7)   Any other information that the Cleburne Conference Center Manager
may deem reasonably necessary in order to determine whether to issue a
reservation.
   (E)   Applications for reservations shall be filed with the Conference
Center Manager no more than 365 days before the date of the activity, event or
use.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)
§ 101.042 PROCEDURES OF ISSUANCE OF RESERVATIONS.
   (A)    A reservation shall be issued unless it is found:
      (1)    That the proposed activity, event or use of these facilities will
unreasonably interfere with other scheduled users of the facility;
      (2)    The proposed activity, event or use of these facilities will
unreasonably interfere with the public health, safety or welfare of other users
and/or the general public;
      (3)    That the conduct of the proposed activity, event or use is
reasonably likely to result in or create a clear and present danger of violence
to persons or property resulting in serious harm to the public;
      (4)    That the facility desired has already been reserved for another
activity, event or use at the same day and hour requested in the reservation
application;
      (5)    That false or misleading information is contained in the
reservation application or required information is omitted;
      (6)    That the event would violate any federal, state or municipal law;
or
      (7)   (a)   Definitions. For the purpose of this subchapter, the
following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning.
            COMPETING SHOW. An event which has 35% or more of its net square
footage of exhibit space showing/selling product lines or businesses the same
or substantially similar to those in the client’s show. However, a show that is
open to the public shall not be deemed a competing show with a show open only
to the trade.
            PROTECTION CLAUSE. Center agrees that it will not lease any portion
of the facility to any competing show within the protection period.
         (b)   Protection clause. A protection clause may be granted by Center
to recurring consumer or trade shows that have a proven record of success in
the region, and which have produced significant local economic benefit. If
granted, the protection clause will offer protection 45 days on either side of
the show (protection period) from a competing show. The determination whether
or not an event is a competing show is solely within the discretion of the
Center Manager and shall be based upon the target audience, product lines and/
or business listings or prospects from both events. In the event a show’s
audience, product lines or businesses change and is then deemed to be a
competing show, the reservation will be in violation of the agreement and will
result in cancellation of this agreement and forfeiture of all payments made by
the client. No client may reserve the Center 45 days on either side of an event
that is substantially similar.
   (B)   The Cleburne Conference Center Manager may impose reasonable
conditions or restrictions on the granting of a reservation, including but not
limited to any of the following:
      (1)   Restrictions on fires, amplified sound, use of alcoholic beverages,
dancing, sports activities, use of animals, equipment or vehicle use, the
number of persons in attendance, the location of any bandstand or stage or any
other use which may appear likely to create a risk of harm to the use and
enjoyment of the Cleburne Conference Center and the senior citizens center.
      (2)    A requirement that the applicant post a reasonable deposit of
security for the repair of any damage to these facilities or the cost of clean-
up or both.
      (3)   A requirement that the applicant furnish adequate security forces
as determined by Conference Center Manager or Cleburne Police Chief or his
designee during the proposed use or activity. Cleburne Police Department Off-
Duty Security and Traffic Control Policy will apply.
      (4)    A requirement that the reserving party furnish additional sanitary
and/or refuse facilities that might be reasonably necessary, based on the use
or activity for which the reservation is being sought.
   (C)   Reservations shall not be transferrable without the written consent of
the Cleburne Conference Center Manager.
   (D)   Any aggrieved person who is denied a reservation shall have the right
to appeal, in writing, within five days to the City Manager, who shall consider
the request and either sustain or overrule the Cleburne Conference Center
Manager's decision.
   (E)    A reserving party shall be bound by all rules and regulations and all
applicable ordinances fully as though the same were inserted in his
reservation.
   (F)    The person or persons to whom the reservation is issued shall be
liable for any loss, damage or injury to any person or property whatsoever by
reason of the negligence of the person or persons to whom such reservation is
issued.
   (G)   The Community Services Division Director or the Cleburne Conference
Center Manager shall have the authority to revoke a reservation upon finding of
a violation of any rule, ordinance, state, federal or local law or upon the
violation of any condition or restriction under which the reservation was
issued.
   (H)    Reservations shall be made in person by the responsible person.
   (I)   If approved, it will be the applicant's responsibility to pick up the
reservation from the Cleburne Conference Center Manager or it may be mailed
upon request.
   (J)   A separate reservation book shall be kept on the Cleburne Conference
Center and the senior citizens center.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12; Am.
Ord. 05-2014-32, passed 5-13-14; Am. Ord. 09-2019-08, passed 2-12-19)
§ 101.043 DUTIES OF THE COMMUNITY SERVICES DIRECTOR, CITY MANAGER OR HIS
DESIGNEE.
   The Community Services Division Director or the City Manager's designee
shall have the authority to make, from time to time, such reasonable rules and
regulations as are necessary to manage, preserve and govern the Cleburne
Conference Center and the senior citizens center property, buildings and
activities, and to exempt reserving parties of these facilities from certain
requirements of this chapter if he deems it in the best interest of the city.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12; Am.
Ord. 03-2018-24, passed 3-27-18)
FEE PAYMENT
§ 101.050 RENTAL FEE PAYMENTS.
   Rental fees and deposits must be paid at least 14 days prior to the date of
the event to avoid cancellation.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99)
§ 101.051 CANCELLATION OF RESERVATION.
   If cancellations are received by the Cleburne Conference Center Manager at
any time prior to 14 days before the date of the event, a full refund shall be
made. No refunds will be made for cancellations after fourteen (14) days.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)

   (A)   Conference Center Room Rates Table.

   (B)   Other fees.
      (1)   For-profit users.
         (a)   Alcohol.
            1.   Deposit. A $300 alcohol deposit shall be required and will be
refunded contingent upon meeting the $300 minimum bar fee.
            2.   Security fee. Cleburne Police Officers, shall be reserved
through the Conference Center and must be on duty as follows or as determined
by Police Chief or his designee: 1 to 100 guests - two officers; 101 to 300
guests - three officers; 301 to 500 guests - four officers; 501 and over,
number of officers will be determined by Cleburne Police Chief or his designee.
In the event, Cleburne Police Officers are not available for the required
security, the Police Chief or his designee may allow off-duty officers from
other agencies, but proof of general liability (bodily injury/property damage/
indemnification for litigation arising from off-duty employment) must be
provided prior to the event. There is a two-hour minimum per Officer. Officers
will be paid directly by the lessee at the current market rate as referenced in
the Cleburne Police Department Off-Duty and Traffic Control policy. All other
conditions of the policy will apply.
         (b)   Caterers' permit. This is a yearly fee of $25 charged to
caterers utilizing the Cleburne Conference Center. They must have a City of
Cleburne Health Permit in place before receiving the permit. Payment will be
made through Conference Center office.
         (c)   Stages. Stages come in sections of 4 x 8 feet each. These are
charged per piece at a rate of $10 each.

at $25.

remove your items requiring use of an aerial lift (congruent with our current
rules and regulations) at a base fee of $25 per hour, with a one hour minimum.

per room.

room.

   This service is provided upon request from those individuals or
organizations who desire a cleanup service after their use of the facility.
However, not all requests are given this option. Most dances and private
parties are required to provide their own cleanup.

§ 101.060 CLASSIFICATION OF FACILITY USES DEFINITIONS.
CLASS I: MEETINGS OR FUND RAISERS
   This class applies to any gathering for the purpose of holding a meeting
only, private or professional. It also applies to persons, organizations and
associations considered non-commercial when the event to be held is to raise
money and when receipts are donated to a charity or community-benefit project
for which such function is intended. This can include dances.
CLASS II: BANQUETS OR PARTIES
   This class applies to any gathering for the purpose of holding an activity
or meeting with food being prepared or served. This will include banquets,
class reunions, family reunions, parties, weddings and receptions.
CLASS III: COMMERCIAL DANCES
   This class applies to any gathering for the purpose of engaging in a dance
activity open to the public where an admission fee is charged. This class will
include Quinceaneras (15th birthday celebrations).
CLASS IV: COMMERCIAL USES
   This class applies to any gathering other than dances where an admission fee
is charged.
CLASS V: CIVIC CLUBS, SCHOOLS, COUNTY, & CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
   This class applies to non-profit organizations whose purpose is for
community service. This is for regular meetings of these groups only and these
meetings are subject to be moved to another room at any time to accommodate
another classification being setup or held.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99)
§ 101.061 DAMAGE DEPOSIT FEE.
   For all dances that allow alcoholic beverages, a damage fee of $1,000.00
will be charged. For all other events, the Cleburne Conference Center Manager
has the discretion to charge a minimum of $250.00 and a maximum of $500.00 if
it is determined such activity might cause damage to the facilities.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 04-2012-13, passed 4-10-12)
§ 101.062 ANNUAL RESERVATIONS.
   Reservations made on an annual basis for activities occurring either weekly,
monthly or annually, shall be allowed to be renewed automatically if requested.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99)
§ 101.063 SENIOR CITIZEN EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS.
   Educational programs that are offered to senior citizen groups at the senior
citizen center that do not require an admission fee to attend, nor any charge
for the providing of same, shall be allowed without a rental fee being
assessed.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99)
§ 101.064 SENIOR CITIZENS ADVISORY BOARD SPONSORED ACTIVITIES.
   Activities that are sponsored by the Senior Citizens Advisory Board shall be
allowed without a rental fee or janitorial service fee being assessed.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99, Am.Ord. 04-2000-31, passed 4-25-00)
§ 101.999 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, corporation, agent or employee thereof who violates any of
the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon
conviction thereof shall be fined not to exceed $500 for each offense. Each day
that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 10-1999-108, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 05-2011-24, passed 5-10-11; Am.
Ord. 03-2012-12, passed 3-27-12; Am. Ord. 06-2012-24, passed 6-12-12)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 102.001 TERM DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this section, the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein:
   DEPARTMENT. The City of Cleburne W. J. Layland Museum Department.
   DIRECTOR. The Community Services Director.
   MUSEUM ADVISORY BOARD OR "BOARD". That body established pursuant to this
chapter.
   MUSEUM CURATOR. That individual charged with the responsibilities of
overseeing the maintenance and care of all museum facilities and artifacts.
   MUSEUM COLLECTIONS. Those items of historical or educational significance
held by the Museum as permanent acquisitions or as temporary loans.
   STREET TRAIN. A tractor/trailer vehicle used for tours and special events to
transport people.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.002 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to establish rules and regulations for the
Museum facilities of the city, designed for the use and enjoyment of the
citizens and visitors of the city.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.003 MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL OF MUSEUM.
   The public museum of the city and all the facilities located therein shall
be under the management and control of the City Manager or his duly appointed
Community Services Division Director who shall be responsible to the City
Manager in the conduct and affairs of the Museum Department.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.004 MUSEUM DEPARTMENT CREATED.
   There shall be a department of city government to be known as the Museum
Department. Said department shall be under the immediate supervision of the
Museum Curator. The Museum Department shall be part of the Community Services
Division and as such, is under the direct supervision and control of the
Community Services Division Director.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.005 DUTIES OF THE MUSEUM CURATOR.
   To facilitate the operation of the public museum, a suitable person shall be
appointed Museum Curator by the Community Services Division Director with the
approval of the City manager. The Curator shall have authority to administer
the museum under the direction and review of the Community Services Division
Director. The Curator shall be held responsible for the care of the museum
collections and historic structures; employment, training and supervising of
museum staff; appropriate and efficient public services and operation of the
museum under the financial conditions set forth in the annual operating budget.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.006 DUTIES OF THE COMMUNITY SERVICES DIVISION DIRECTOR.
   Subject to the approval of the City Manager, the Community Services Division
Director shall be responsible for determining overall policies, regulations and
programs governing acquisition, improvement, maintenance and operation of all
museum facilities, artifacts, equipment and the grounds surrounding all museum
facilities. The Community Services Division Director shall be responsible to
the City Manager for administration and implementation of the policies
established by the City Council in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.007 APPOINTMENT OF EMPLOYEES.
   The Community Services Division Director shall have the power to appoint,
employ and remove such other officers, assistants, employees and personnel as
he may deem necessary for the efficient administration of the affairs of the
Museum Department, and to prescribe and fix their duties, scope of authority
and qualifications in accordance with the annual budget of the Museum
Department as adopted by the City Council and the classification and
compensation plan established by the City Council, all under the approval of
the City Manager.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.008 JURISDICTION.
   The rules and regulations in this chapter shall be enforced in all museum
facilities of the city unless specifically exempted by this chapter.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.009 CONDITIONS FOR USE; ENFORCEMENT.
   Compliance with rules and regulations of this chapter is a condition of the
use of museum facilities of the city.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
MUSEUM ADVISORY BOARD
§ 102.015 BOARD CREATED; MEMBERSHIP, TERM AND VACANCIES.
   (A)    There is hereby created and established a Museum Advisory Board for
the City of Cleburne, Texas.
   (B)   It shall be composed of nine members, five of whom must reside in the
city and four of whom may reside outside the city but must reside in Johnson
County during the term of their appointment by the City Council. The President
of the Cleburne Railroad Museum Group, a local 501(c)(3) non-profit
organization, shall serve as one of the nine members. A member of the Museum
Advisory Board shall hold office at the pleasure of the City Council provided,
however, that the term of office shall in no event, without reappointment,
exist for a longer period than two years or until a successor is appointed.
   (C)   The Museum Curator shall serve as an ex-officio member of the board
with no voting privileges.
   (D)   Vacancies on the Board shall be filled in the same manner for the
duration of the term of a position being vacated.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99; Am. Ord. 2-2002-12, passed 2-26- 02; Am.
Ord. 10-2018-80, passed 10-9-18)
§ 102.016 ELECTION OF OFFICERS.
   (A)    The members of the Museum Advisory Board shall meet and organize by
electing a president and treasurer. The Board shall establish such rules and
regulations for the governing of same, as in its judgement may be deemed
necessary and proper.
   (B)    Officers of the Board shall be elected annually at the first meeting
in January or at other appropriate times to fill vacancies. Officers so elected
will take office at the next board meeting following their election.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.017 DUTIES OF BOARD OFFICERS.
   (A)    The president shall preside at all meetings, appoint special
committees as needed and authorize calls for any special meetings.
   (B)    If so desired by the Board, museum staff may serve as secretary
keeping a true and accurate account of all meetings and proceedings. Museum
staff shall have custody of the permanent record of minutes of the Board.
   (C)    The Treasurer shall be familiar with expenditures and balances of the
monies of the Board held by the City in a special revenue fund. The treasurer
shall make a financial report at each meeting of the Board.
   (D)    Nominating committee for new board members shall consist of the
president and Museum Curator and other such Board members as appointed by the
president. In the case where the Board desires to make nominations for vacant
positions on the board, more than one name shall be submitted to the City
Council for consideration. Said nominations shall be forwarded by the Community
Services Division Director to the City Council for their consideration and
review. The City Council is not bound by this list of names when considering
persons for appointment to the Museum Advisory Board.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.018 CONDUCT OF BUSINESS.
   The Museum Advisory Board shall serve in an advisory capacity to the City
Council concerning the acquisition, maintenance, operation and use of museum
facilities, equipment and grounds and shall conduct its business at such times
and under such rules and regulations as it may prescribe.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.019 DUTIES OF THE BOARD.
   (A)    It shall be the duty of the Museum Advisory Board to create, and
revise as necessary, a mission statement to guide the Museum in artifact
acquisitions and program planning.
   (B)    It shall confer and work with the Museum Department to make
recommendations to the City Council relating to developmental plans.
   (C)    It shall assist and recommend programs of education for all age
levels, for the effective implementation of such programs and to assist the
City Council in development and adoption of such plans and recommendations in
every way possible.
   (D)    The Museum Advisory Board shall have the advisory input to the
general supervision and control of all matters pertaining to the Museum
Department and shall advise on matters concerning the rules and regulations
pertaining to the operation and use of Museum facilities.
   (E)    It is hereby made the duty and province of the Museum Advisory Board
to make recommendations and suggestions to the City Council for the betterment
and improvement of the museum facilities, acquisitions and activities.
   (F)   Implementation of any and all projects or goals recommended by the
Museum Advisory Board is subject to approval of the City Manager.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.020 COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS.
   Members of the Museum Advisory Board shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.021 CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
   Members of the Museum Advisory Board shall avoid situations where conflict
of interest may occur by refraining from personally collecting objects sought
by the Museum for the permanent collection.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.022 EXPENDITURE OF CITY FUNDS.
   The Museum Advisory Board shall have no authority to make expenditures of
city funds, nor to order any work done on its authority. The Board does have
the authority to expend funds from the Museum Board Funds account in accordance
with city financial policies.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.023 VISITORS TO BOARD MEETINGS.
   The Board shall welcome representatives from local preservation, theatrical,
or educational organizations as well as the general public to the meetings.
Such representatives and public shall have no voting authority.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.024 MEETINGS GENERALLY.
   The Museum Advisory Board shall hold such regular meetings as may be
determined by the Board, and as many other special or called meetings as may be
deemed proper and regular under the rules established by the Board.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.025 QUORUM AND RULES OF PARLIAMENTARY LAW.
   Five members of the Museum Advisory Board shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business, and the general rules of parliamentary law shall be
enforced in all proceedings of the Board.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.026 NO SUPERVISORY POWERS.
   The Museum Advisory Board shall have no authority to employ or discharge
employees of the Museum Department. The Board shall not have authority over the
duty assignments of the Museum Department employees.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.027 BOARD GENERATED FUNDS.
   The Museum Advisory Board may elect to sponsor a function or activity for
the purpose of raising funds, gathering donations, or securing contributions
which shall be used for the strict purpose of enhancement of museum facilities,
procurement of equipment or artifacts, renovation of museum facilities or any
other purpose directly related to the museum operation. These funds shall be
deposited in the treasury of the City and kept separate in a fund established
for same.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.028 MUSEUM BOARD BY-LAWS; POLICIES AND MISSION STATEMENT.
   (A)    The Museum Advisory Board shall create a set of by-laws to govern the
Board.
   (B)    The Museum Advisory Board shall create its policies and mission
statement.
   (C)    The Museum by-laws, policies and mission statement may be amended at
any regular meeting of the Board when a quorum is present by a unanimous vote,
providing the amendment is listed in the agenda of the meeting.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
MUSEUM OPERATIONS AND OBLIGATIONS; PERMANENT COLLECTION
   The Museum's permanent collection and exhibit materials represent the
cultural common wealth of the region. As steward of that wealth, the Museum is
compelled to collect, preserve,exhibit, and educate with materials owned or
borrowed for these ends. The collections are the basis for research, exhibits,
and programs that invite public participation. The Museum follows the Code of
Ethics as set forth by the American Association of Museums.
§ 102.035 ACQUISITION OF ARTIFACTS.
   (A)    Artifacts received into the permanent collection, or by loan of
owner, must be relevant and complement the purposes and activities of the
Museum as described in the mission statement.
   (B)    Professional standards for storage and long-term preservation must be
assured for all objects received into the collection.
   (C)    Artifacts shall have permanency in the collections as long as their
physical integrity, authenticity, and usefulness for the purposes of the Museum
can be maintained.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.036 TITLE TO ARTIFACTS.
   (A)    Objects acquired for the collections should be obtained free and
clear, and without restrictions as to use or future disposition.
   (B)    A legal instrument of conveyance, or gift agreement, setting forth an
adequate description of the objects involved, and precise conditions of
transfer will be kept on file at the Museum. Unconditional gifts must be signed
by the donor.
   (C)    Objects on loan from owner shall have a loan agreement executed
setting forth an adequate description of the objects involved, owner
information and terms and conditions of the loan.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.037 ACCESSION AND INVENTORY RECORDS.
   (A)    Accession and inventory records of all objects, and other property
owned or controlled by the Museum, shall be maintained, including: detailed
description, condition report, date acquired, whether gift or loan, and donor
information.
   (B)    When possible, photographs should be made for identification
purposes.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.038 CARE OF COLLECTIONS.
   (A)    The Curator shall be responsible for ensuring acceptable standards in
handling, exhibiting, transporting, and storing of all objects in the permanent
collection. A written collections procedural manual will be prepared and
followed.
   (B)    Environmental protection will be provided to the collection
including, but not limited to, prevention of damage from unfiltered ultraviolet
light, extremes in temperature and humidity, pests, theft, and water.
   (C)    Staff, volunteers, and other personnel having access to the
collection will be trained in proper methods of handling.
   (D)    The unique and special nature of human remains, funerary, and sacred
objects is recognized as the basis of all decisions concerning such collection
objects.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.039 PUBLIC ACCESS TO COLLECTIONS.
   (A)    Requests for retrieval of objects not exhibited for purposes of study
by researchers or visits by the donor family will be honored whenever possible
and when sufficient Museum staff is available.
   (B)    Copies of images from the historic photograph collection may be made
available to the public for a fee.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.040 LOANS OR TRANSFERS.
   (A)    That greater exposure be gained from the permanent collection, loans
or transfers of objects may be approved when sufficient study of the requesting
institution merits acceptance. Such action shall be preceded by: recommendation
of the curator, approval of Museum Board and permission of the City Manager.
   (B)    A record of loans shall be maintained by the curator and renewed
annually.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.041 DEACCESSIONS.
   (A)    The responsibility of creating a permanent collection to support the
mission of the Museum and to direct limited resources toward the artifacts most
likely to survive another century, suggests that objects will be deaccessioned
when their physical integrity diminishes to the point of serving no purpose for
exhibits or research.
   (B)    Such action will be preceded by: recommendation of the curator,
approval of the Museum Board, and permission of the City Manager.
   (C)    No donated object shall be deaccessioned for any reason for two years
after the date of its acquisition. (See U. S. Tax Reform Act of 1984 and 1. R.
S. regulations)
   (D)    Every attempt shall be made to contact the donor family. If the donor
is deceased, the executor of the estate is responsible for negotiations with
the Museum.
   (E)    A complete record of all deaccessions will be maintained by the
curator.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
EXHIBITS AND PROGRAMS
   The Museum shall serve the community by advancing knowledge of the cultural
commonwealth through exhibits, research, scholarship, publications, and
educational programs.
§ 102.045 EXHIBITED COLLECTIONS.
   (A)    Exhibits of historical objects shall be for public appreciation,
education, and enlightenment.
   (B)    Only objects deemed "exhibit quality" and in stable condition shall
be exhibited.
   (C)    The utmost care shall be given to exhibited artifacts when: cleaning,
preparing, transporting, and mounting. Objects shall be secured against
environmental damage and/or theft. Accession numbers shall be preserved on
exhibited objects.
   (D)    Objects shall be rotated and "rested" from exhibit at the discretion
of the curator to secure the longest possible life of the object.
   (E)    Interpretative labels and text for exhibited items will be prepared
in both English and Spanish, whenever possible.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.046 PROGRAMS.
   (A)    Public programs shall support the mission of the Museum. Revenue-
producing activities and those involving external entities likewise shall be
compatible with the Museum's mission and support its public trust
responsibilities.
   (B)    Programs shall be based on scholarship, accuracy, and truth in
presentation.
   (C)    Programs shall be designed for accessibility to the widest possible
audience.
   (D)    Programs shall respect pluralistic values, traditions, and concerns.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
FACILITY USE RULES AND REGULATIONS
   The primary purpose of the Museum complex of historic structures shall be to
provide exhibit and storage space for the city-owned artifact collection. These
spaces shall be reserved for city functions, departmental meetings, educational
programs, receptions, and other events appropriate to the limitations of the
structures. Museum facilities shall be made available for rent by non-profit
organizations when agreement is reached on the necessary limitations of use.
§ 102.050 HISTORIC SIGNIFICANCE.
   (A)    The Layland Museum main building was formerly the old Carnegie
Library. As one of only twelve remaining in Texas, it is one of the State's
most important historic structures. In 1978, it was listed on the National
Register of Historic Places. In 1981, it was designated a Recorded Texas
Historic Landmark (RTHL). In 1992, it was listed as a State Archeological
Landmark.
   (B)    The Doty-Fullerton House, 409 N. Buffalo Street, is considered to be
the oldest existing residence in the city, ca. 1868. In 1965, it was designated
a Recorded Texas Historic Landmark (RTHL).
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.051 REVENUE.
   All proceeds from the rental/use of Museum facilities shall be itemized and
forwarded on a regular schedule to the Finance Department according to the City
financial policies.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.052 PERFORMANCE THEATER, HISTORIC HOUSE, AND GROUNDS.
   (A)    Groups desiring to rent the theater or historic house shall make
written application with the Museum curator well before the planned event. Fees
and deposits shall be paid in advance to secure the reservation.
   (B)    Organizations shall appoint a representative, over the age of 21
years, to be responsible for receiving keys to the building and security codes.
Keys and codes shall not be passed among other members of the organization, nor
family members, without permission from the curator.
   (C)    The conduct of all group members, technical crews, visitors or
audience members is the responsibility of the renting organization. Ushers
shall be appointed to provide assistance on stairs during theater events.
Accidents shall be promptly reported to the curator.
   (D)    Food and beverages shall be strictly controlled in the historic
structures.
   (E)    Open flames, cigarettes, matches, chafing dish fuels, and burning
candles shall not be permitted in the structures.
   (F)    Decorations, stage sets, and other ornamental embellishments are
subject to approval by the City Fire Marshal before an event opening.
   (G)    Premises shall be swept and trash generated by the event shall be
removed by the renting party. A walk-through inspection with the curator is
required before the damage deposit is returned.
   (H)    Arrangements may be made to have the structure cleaned at an
additional fee to the renting organization.
   (I)    Artifacts or other equipment within the structure which must be moved
for the event shall be moved by Museum staff
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
§ 102.053 MUSEUM STREET TRAIN.
   (A)    Use policy, license plates, motor vehicle inspection sticker,
insurance, repairs and general maintenance shall be the responsibility of the
Museum Department.
   (B)    Scheduled maintenance shall be conducted by the Fleet Maintenance
Department.
   (C)    The Museum curator shall be responsible for interviewing drivers and
tour guides and securing training for the operation of the street train.
   (D)    No person, other than approved drivers, shall be allowed to operate
the train.
   (E)    The driver shall be responsible for the safe operation of the train
and must obey all traffic laws.
   (F)    The driver shall be responsible to maintain order and see that
passengers conduct themselves in a safe and responsible manner.
   (G)    The driver shall immediately report all accidents or injuries to the
curator.
   (H)    The street train shall not be loaned for out-of-town use without the
written permission of the City Manager.
   (I)    No food or beverages shall be allowed on the train. Use of the street
train shall be by reservation. A schedule of operations shall be maintained by
the Museum staff.
   (J)    Use of the train will be scheduled as drivers are available.
   (K)    Prepaid reservations shall be made at least five working days prior
to date of use.
   (L)    The Museum curator or representative reserves the right to cancel any
reservation for inclement weather or other circumstances preventing the
operation of the street train.
   (M)    Reservations unable to come and not cancelling at least 48 hours in
advance of use will be billed the full reservation amount.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
PHOTOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
§ 102.060 PHOTOGRAPHIC COLLECTION RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (A)    Copies of historic photographs that are in the Museum's collection
and that are in stable condition may be purchased by individuals according to
the fee schedule in this chapter.
   (B)    All requests for permission to reproduce an image for publication
purposes shall be made in writing and include the intended use, the publisher
and the expected date of publication.
   (C)    All fees or charges for image or photographic reproduction shall be
paid in advance, whether or not the reproduction is used by the requesting
individual.
   (D)    Reproductions may not be superimposed with type matter or in any way
defaced or altered.
   (E)    Application to reproduce a detail from a work will be considered only
upon receipt of a marked photograph showing the exact area to be used. The word
"detail" must appear in the caption with a complete credit line. Under most
circumstances, an application for detailing may be approved only if the work is
shown in its entirety elsewhere in the publication.
   (F)    Permission for book jackets or calendar covers will only be
considered upon receipt of a cover design and written application for such use.
An additional fee is required for cover use.
   (G)    The credit line must appear adjacent to each illustration and must
read: Courtesy, Layland Museum, Cleburne, Texas.
   (H)    Special projects such as notecards, address books, and calendars must
be presented to the Layland Museum for consideration and charges. A sample of
the publication must accompany the request.
   (I)    The Museum shall not supply black and white photographs to companies,
organizations or individuals operating a photography rental and/or sales
service.
   (J)    Applicants shall not duplicate, in any way, a photograph or image
supplied by the Museum.
   (K)    The publisher shall provide the Museum with one complete gratis copy
of the publication in which the image or photograph is reproduced.
   (L)    Any and all responsibility for questions of copyright which may arise
from the preparation of these reproductions or their use in any way will be
assumed by the applicant and the applicant will hold harmless the city, its
officers and its employees.
(Ord. 10-1999-109, passed 10-12-99)
FEE SCHEDULE

   (A)    There shall be a fee or charge for the use of museum facilities.
