LEGAL PROVISIONS
 § 156.01 TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known as the Cleburne Sign Code and referenced as
"this chapter" or as "Sign Code."
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.02 AUTHORITY.
   (A)   Texas State Law. The following chapters and sections of the laws of
the State of Texas establish the city's authority that is exercised within this
chapter:
      (1)   Texas Local Government Code, including:
         (a)   Chapter 216 (Regulation of Signs by Municipalities).
      (2)   Texas Transportation Code, including:
         (a)   Chapter 391 (Highway Beautification on Interstate and Primary
Systems and Certain Roads).
         (b)   Chapter 392 (Highway Beautification on State Highway Right-of-
Way).
         (c)   Chapter 393 (Outdoor Signs on Public Rights-of-Way).
         (d)   Chapter 394 (Outdoor Signs on Rural Roads).
         (e)   Chapter 544 (Traffic Signs, Signals, and Markings).
   (B)   Exercise of powers. This chapter is adopted in the exercise of the
power granted by municipalities by these statutes, the City Charter of
Cleburne, and the Texas Constitution.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.03 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to regulate signs of all types (temporary and
permanent) in a manner that:
   (A)   Protects constitutional rights to free speech by preserving
opportunities for expression through signs, while avoiding content-based
distinctions, and providing clear approval standards;
   (B)   Protects public health and safety by:
      (1)   Minimizing visual traffic hazards, distractions, and obstructions
for motorists, cyclists, and pedestrians, or signs causing confusion by virtue
of visual similarity to traffic control signs;
      (2)   Not creating a nuisance to persons using the public rights-of-way;
      (3)   Not causing a nuisance to occupancy of adjacent and contiguous
property by their brightness, size, height, or movement;
      (4)   Minimizing obstructions to firefighting or police surveillance; and
      (5)   Encouraging the upgrading, updating, or removing signs that are
poorly maintained, or do not conform to this chapter, and preventing signs that
are potentially dangerous due to structural deficiencies and disrepair from
hazards caused by collapse, fire, collision, decay, or abandonment.
   (C)   Maintains and enhances the aesthetic environment and the city's
ability to attract sources of economic development and growth by providing
those signs:
      (1)   Promote the community's appearance, character, quality, and
business climate by encouraging signs that are attractive and functional for
their intended purpose, and that are in scale and harmony with the development
site and building(s) and with surrounding areas;
      (2)   Reduce and prevent visual clutter or potential deterioration of the
community's appearance and attractiveness;
      (3)   Implements the goals and policies of the city's adopted planning
policies, commercial and historical overlays, zoning regulations, and
International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC) standards by establishing
uniform standards and procedures to regulate the size, type, number, design,
placement, illumination, timeframe for display, and maintenance of signs; and
      (4)   Do not interfere with scenic views.
   (D)   Regulates signs by classifying each sign according to its design and
construction type and by regulating those sign types as they occur within
certain Sign Districts throughout Cleburne. These regulations address the type,
number, size, height, and placement within a site for signs according to their
location in the various Sign Districts.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.04 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   This chapter applies within the city's corporate boundaries, except
as specifically stated otherwise in these sign regulations.
      (2)   This chapter does not prohibit signs required by state or federal
law and does not authorize signs that state or federal law prohibits.
      (3)   No person shall erect, operate, display, or otherwise use any sign
at a time, place, or manner that this chapter prohibits.
   (B)   Exemptions. This chapter does not apply to signs listed in §
156.20.
   (C)   Message neutrality.
      (1)   Content neutrality. Non-commercial speech is not regulated. This
chapter is not intended to limit commercial messaging except to further the
goals and objectives of this chapter. If there are any conflicts between the
regulations of this chapter and a commercial message, the Director will
interpret the regulation so as to create minimal impact on the commercial
message itself.
      (2)   Substitution allowed. Any sign authorized in this chapter may
contain any noncommercial copy or message in place of any other authorized
commercial or noncommercial message without an additional permit or approval so
long as the sign complies with the other requirements of this chapter and other
applicable city ordinances. Message substitution is a continuing right which
may be exercised any number of times. The message substitution right does not:
         (a)   Create a right to increase the total amount of sign display area
on a site or parcel;
         (b)   Create a right to substitute an off-site commercial message in
place of an on-site commercial message;
         (c)   Affect the requirement that a sign structure or mounting device
must be properly permitted;
         (d)   Authorize changing the physical method of image presentation
(such as digital or neon) display without a permit; or
         (e)   Authorize a physical change to the sign structure without
compliance with this chapter or applicable building codes, safety codes, and
applicable rules for sign size, height, orientation, setback, separation, or
illumination.
   (D)   Signs within Planned Developments (PDs).
      (1)   Applicability. This chapter shall apply to signs within a PD unless
otherwise specified within the PD adopting ordinance. To the extent that a sign
plan does not address the type, area, height, design features, or other sign
requirements, this chapter shall apply to those features.
      (2)   Master sign plans. The master sign plan shall comply with the
requirements established in §
156.56.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.05 RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER REGULATIONS.
   Generally, refer to Tex. Local Gov’t Code § 211.013 (Conflict with Other
Laws) if this chapter conflicts with other regulations. Except as provided in
Tex. Local Gov’t Code § 211.013 (Conflict with Other Laws), if any provision of
this chapter conflicts with state or federal law, state or federal law
controls.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.06 RELATIONSHIP TO PRIVATE RESTRICTIONS.
   This chapter does not abrogate any deed restriction, covenant, or any other
private agreement or restriction on the use of signage on private property.
However, if the provisions of this chapter are more restrictive or impose
higher standards than any private restriction, the requirements of this chapter
control. Where the provisions of any private restriction are more restrictive
or impose higher standards than the provisions of this chapter, the private
restrictions control if properly enforced by a person having the legal right to
enforce those restrictions. The city shall not enforce private restrictions.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.07 AMENDMENTS.
   Amendments to this chapter shall be adopted by ordinance of the City
Council. Amendments may be initiated by the City Council or considered upon
recommendation of the City Manager or designated Director. Public hearings or
notices shall be provided at the City Council's discretion, unless otherwise
required by law.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.20 EXEMPT SIGNS.
   (A)   Generally. Changing the face of a sign does not require a sign permit,
provided that the change is made to an existing sign face, without changing the
sign type, height, size, or shape.
   (B)   Exemptions. The following signs are exempt from the regulations of
this chapter:
      (1)   Any signs and signals properly authorized by law, signs authorized
by statute or a state agency in accordance with the Texas Manual of Uniform
Traffic Control Devices, and other traffic signals, public warnings, or legal
notices, provided that such signs or signals are installed in a location and in
a manner and condition required by federal or state statute, a state agency, or
a city ordinance or authorized authority.
      (2)   Nonconforming signs and existing billboards as defined in this
chapter.
      (3)   Signs required or established by governmental bodies or agencies
having proper jurisdiction for a public purpose by law, statute, or ordinance.
This includes any signs:
         (a)   The City Council decides by ordinance or resolution to erect
within its corporate boundaries or on any real property that it may own or
control;
         (b)   Erected by the city (temporarily or otherwise) that directs
vehicular or pedestrian traffic, which may display arrows, words, or other
symbols to indicate directions;
         (c)   Erected by governmental bodies or agencies serving the public;
         (d)   Signage as permitted within any portion of this chapter on
public property with the permission and under the supervision of the city; or
         (e)   In a plaza or public space structures located in the city's
right-of-way, that are installed and maintained by the city or a contractor
authorized by the city.
      (4)   Signs on vehicles, trailers, or equipment are exempted only to the
extent such signs are incidental to the primary use of the vehicle, trailer, or
equipment, provided that the vehicle, trailer, or equipment is in good
mechanical repair and is not left in one place for more than 72 hours without
being moved.
      (5)   Address numerals and other similar information required to be
maintained by law or governmental order, rule or regulation, provided that the
size of the sign may not exceed the requirements of such law, order, rule, or
regulation.
      (6)   Signs contained within a walled, fenced, or secured property or
area that are not visible from a right-of-way.
      (7)   Signs used as score boards in athletic stadiums.
      (8)   Signs located within or immediately adjacent to building entrances
or interior foyers, provided such signs are intended for on-site
identification, directory, or informational purposes and are not designed to be
visible from a public street or right-of-way.
      (9)   Seasonal decorations customarily displayed during federally
recognized holidays.
      (10)   Signs placed on public property designated as an official polling
place on a designated election day so long as such signs are located outside
the specified distance from the polling place entrance as permitted by state
election laws.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.21 PROHIBITED SIGNS.
   The following signs and related objects are prohibited from being installed
or publicly displayed at any location within the city's corporate boundaries,
except as otherwise specifically prescribed within this chapter, and if after
authorized issuance of a city-issued sign permit required by this chapter.
   (A)   New billboards.
   (B)   Moving and flashing signs, including signs that flash, blink, pulse/
pulsate, flicker, revolve, rotate, swing, undulate or otherwise attract
attention through the movement or flashing of lights, LEDs, or other parts, or
through the impression of movement or flashing. However, this prohibition shall
not apply to:
      (1)   Signs that are fully located within an enclosed building that are
not visible from public right-of-way; and
      (2)   Temporary signs that may move or fluctuate and have a valid permit.
   (C)   Signs which employ a motion picture machine, or which display moving
images, or images which give the impression of motion, including those using
digital display.
   (D)   Signs which are of a size, location, movement, content, coloring, or
manner of illumination, which may be confused with or construed as a traffic-
control device or which hide from view any traffic or street sign or signal, or
which obstruct the view in any direction at a street or road intersection. This
also includes signs that use a revolving beam or beacon resembling any
emergency vehicle, or are located or illuminated in such a manner as to obscure
or otherwise interfere with the effectiveness of an official traffic sign,
signal or device, or so as to prevent any traveler on any street from obtaining
a clear view of approaching vehicles for a distance of at least 250 feet along
the street.
   (E)   Signs placed on or affixed to vehicles, trailers, or equipment that
are parked on a public right-of-way, public property, or private property so as
to be visible from a public right-of-way where the apparent purpose is to
direct people to a business or activity located on the same or another nearby
property.
   (F)   No person shall attach any sign, paper or other material to, or paint,
stencil or write anything on, or otherwise mark on any sidewalk, curb, gutter,
street utility pole, tree, shrubs, hydrant, bridge, traffic-control device,
street sign, public building or structure in, on, over, or within a public
street, sidewalk, alley, easement, or right-of-way unless authorized by this
chapter, by the City Council or its delegated representatives.
   (G)   No person shall erect or allow to be erected any sign in, on or over
public rights-of-way and easements, railroad right-of-way or designated fire
lanes unless specifically exempted by this chapter or unless erected under a
valid, unexpired permit as specifically set forth elsewhere in this chapter.
   (H)   Bandit signs for the use of off premise temporary advertising.
   (I)   No person shall paint a sign or attach a sign to the exterior of a
fence or railing except in certain circumstances as determined by the Director.
   (J)   Signs which do not comply with any applicable provision of a building
code, electrical code, or other applicable code or ordinance of the city.
   (K)   Messages displayed from searchlights.
   (L)   Signs that are in disrepair to the extent that the cost of repair
would exceed 50% of the value of a similar sign if purchased new and signs in
danger of falling or that are otherwise unsafe to the public.
   (M)   Signs that display holographic projections of diffracted light.
   (N)   Signs that are located on or that interfere with the use of public
sidewalks, required off-street parking areas, or vehicle maneuvering areas
unless specifically regulated in §§
156.35 through
156.42.
   (O)   A non-traffic sign is prohibited within the sight visibility triangle
at intersections, defined by a diagonal line connecting points 25 feet from the
street corner on each property line or their extensions to the curb lines.
   Figure 1: Site Visibility Triangle
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/948048d06474cac31c32c8809bdeca24f7aca423/
IMAGES/0-0-0-8077.jpg]
   (P)   Signs (illuminated from within or without) that are illuminated in
such a manner, to such intensity, or without shielding that is greater than the
prescribed amounts in §
156.37, so as to constitute a hazard to the operation of motor vehicles upon a
street or substantially interfere with the reasonable enjoyment of property.
   (Q)   Signs located on private property without the consent of the owner of
the property.
   (R)   Off-premise outdoor commercial advertising signs.
   (S)   All signs not expressly allowed, exempted, or permitted under this
chapter.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.22 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Installation.
      (1)   Signs and sign structures shall comply with the city's adopted
building codes and all other regulatory requirements.
      (2)   An applicant shall provide all applicable plans and obtain permits
before installing any sign.
   (B)   Maintenance.
      (1)   All signs, together with any supports, braces, guys and anchors,
structural components and footings, and colors, shall remain in good repair and
be properly maintained.
      (2)   For wall signs, the sign installation area on the building wall
shall be cleaned, patched, and painted upon sign removal.
      (3)   Any defective signs or damaged parts or components of a sign shall
be replaced. Upon notice from the city to replace damaged or missing components
of the sign, the owner has until the time specified in the notice to make the
repairs.
      (4)   All components of a sign shall keep the adjacent properties free of
debris, weeds, trash, or other public nuisances.
      (5)   The Director may enforce the standards as provided in §
156.70 and §
156.71.
   (C)   Vertical clearance for signs projecting over sidewalks, walkways, and
driveways.
      (1)   The bottom edge of any projecting sign, attached awning/canopy
sign, hanging sign, marquee sign, and any other sign that extends or projects
over a sidewalk, walkway, or driveway shall be at least eight feet above grade
as shown in §
156.35, unless specified elsewhere in this chapter.
      (2)   Projecting signs, attached awning/canopy signs, hanging signs,
marquee signs, and any other sign that extends or projects over public
sidewalks shall not extend into or occupy more than half the width of the
sidewalk or five feet (whichever is less), as measured from the building wall.
   (D)   Signs in right-of-way. No person shall place or install a sign or
supporting structures within the right-of-way of any public street except as
provided in §
156.57.
   (E)   Administrative interpretations. Interpretations of this chapter are to
be made initially by the Director. All interpretations of this chapter are to
be exercised considering the message neutrality and message substitution
policies. Where a particular type of sign is proposed, and the type is neither
expressly allowed nor prohibited by this chapter, or whenever a sign does not
qualify as a "structure" as defined in the building code, as adopted by the
city, the Director shall approve or disapprove the application based on the
most similar sign type that is legal under the current code, using physical and
structural similarity, that is expressly regulated by this chapter. Appeal to
the City Council over denial of an application may be taken, as provided in §
156.59.
   (F)   Responsibility for compliance. The responsibility for compliance with
this chapter rests jointly and severally upon the sign owner, the permit
holder, all parties holding the present right of possession, and control of the
property where a sign is located, mounted, or installed.
   (G)   Billboards. New billboards are prohibited. Existing legal
nonconforming billboards may not be converted to digital billboards.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.23 SIGN TYPES.
   (A)   Purpose.
      (1)   This chapter establishes the required standards for signs from the
following sign categories:
         (a)   Detached signs;
         (b)   Attached signs;
         (c)   Incidental signs;
         (d)   Temporary signs;
         (e)   Special signs;
         (f)   Vehicle signs; and
         (g)   Historical signs.
      (2)   This classification system provides flexibility for persons and
businesses who display signs, avoids sign distinctions that depend on a sign's
message, supports the community's aesthetic goals, and avoids potential traffic
hazards and clutter.
   (B)   Generally. Sections and subsections in §§
156.35  through
156.42 for each sign type address the following standards:
      (1)   An introductory paragraph defining the sign type;
      (2)   Images or graphics that illustrate the sign type;
      (3)   A table summarizing the applicable sign standards, including:
         (a)   If the sign type is allowed in the designated areas provided in
§
156.35;
         (b)   If a sign permit is required;
         (c)   The maximum number of signs of each type;
         (d)   Maximum sign dimensions, including:
            1.   Sign area;
            2.   Height;
            3.   Location/setbacks; and
            4.   Other requirements.
         (e)   If the sign features provided in §
156.25 are allowed or required:
            1.   Electronic message centers;
            2.   Illumination features; and
            3.   Changeable copies; and
            4.   Neon.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.24 COMPUTATION AND INTERPRETATION.
   (A)   Sign area, sign faces and sign application.
      (1)   Sign area. Sign area means the area enclosed by the smallest
imaginary regular shape (e.g., parallelogram, triangle, circle, trapezoid) or
combination of regular shapes that will encompass the extreme limits of the
writing, representation, emblem, or other display, or combination thereof,
together with any material or color forming an integral part of the display or
used to differentiate the sign from the backdrop or structure against which it
is placed. Sign area includes such features as decorative or ornamental
elements or features, borders, trims, but not including the architectural
enclosure or supporting structure which is used solely for support of the sign,
such as poles, columns and cables, pylons, or other architectural enclosures.
      (2)   Sign faces. When a sign has multiple faces, the sign area shall be
calculated as follows:
         (a)   One-sided sign. The area will be the area of the one face.
         (b)   Two-sided sign, front and back. The sign area is calculated
separately for each side. The area of each side shall not exceed the maximum
permitted sign area.
         (c)   Signs faces on different planes of a sign structure.
            1.   Two sign faces where the interior angle between the two faces
is 45 degrees or less. The sign area is calculated separately for each sign
face. The maximum permitted sign area applies to each sign face.
            2.   Two sign faces where the interior angle between the two faces
is greater than 45 degrees. The sign area is the sum of the individual sign
faces. The combined sign area of the two faces shall not exceed the maximum
permitted sign area.
   Figure 2: Measurement of Sign Face (1 or 2 faces)
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/948048d06474cac31c32c8809bdeca24f7aca423/
IMAGES/0-0-0-8079.jpg]
            3.   Where more than two sign faces exist on a single sign
structure, the sign area is the sum of the individual sign faces. The combined
sign area of the faces shall not exceed the maximum permitted sign area as
shown in the graphic below.
         (d)   All signs on a single supporting structure shall be measured
together as though they were one sign to determine the total sign area, except
that signs separated by more than 36 inches of air space at every point between
the signs, and not separated by being located on different planes of a sign
structure, shall be measured separately and added together to determine the
total sign area.
         (e)   Irregular shaped signs. The sign area is the area enclosed by
the smallest imaginary regular shape, or combination of shapes, which would
fully contain all portions of the sign when rotated horizontally around the
sign. Marquee signs are not considered freeform if information is only
displayed on the front and back.
   (B)   Manner of measurement. The measurement required for signs by this
chapter shall be made using the following procedures:
      (1)   Setback. To apply the setback provisions of this chapter for signs
at any one point, the following measuring procedure shall be used:
         (a)   Draw an imaginary vertical line extending upwards from the curb-
line of the premises;
         (b)   Beginning at any point on the vertical line, draw an imaginary
horizontal line perpendicular to the vertical line and curb-line extending
toward the premises; and
         (c)   Beginning at the point where the vertical line intersects the
horizontal line, measure along the horizontal line for the required setback.
      (2)   Height. The maximum height of a sign mounted to the ground shall be
determined by the method of measurement that allows the greater height, as
follows:
         (a)   Curb-line measurement. Measure along a vertical line extended
upward from the nearest curb-line of the public street fronting the premises
where the sign is to be located, to the maximum height allowed for the sign.
From that point, extend a horizontal line to where the sign is to be located.
The horizontal line is the maximum height allowed at that location for that
Sign District.
         (b)   Street level measurement. Along US Highway 67 and the Chisholm
Trail Parkway, the height of a sign may be measured from the principal lane,
the frontage road, or the ground, whichever allows the greatest height. At the
highest point of the sign, draw a horizontal line to the outer extremities of
the sign. At the center of the horizontal line, draw a vertical line to the
street level (the level of the principal lane, the frontage road or the
ground). The vertical line may not exceed the height allowed for a sign at that
location for that Sign District.
         (c)   Natural ground level measurement. At the highest point of the
sign, draw a horizontal line to the outer extremities of the sign. At the
center of the horizontal line, draw a vertical line to the natural ground level
below (the "natural ground level" shall include any changes in topography
necessary for development of the property). The vertical line may not exceed
the height allowed for the sign at that location for that Sign District.
   (C)   Sign measurement variables. Signs may be allocated by:
      (1)   Lot;
      (2)   Storefront;
      (3)   Entrance;
      (4)   Grounded canopy;
      (5)   Window; or
      (6)   Building.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.25 SIGN FEATURES.
   Signs may incorporate the following features established below; however,
these features shall only be allowed as established in the tables in §
156.35.
   (A)   Illumination.
      (1)   Generally.
         (a)   A sign that is "illuminated" means any sign that incorporates
illumination on or in the sign, or that directs illumination toward or over all
or part of the sign, or that is created by the projection of illuminations onto
a surface (such as a building wall).
         (b)   Permanent signs may be illuminated by static and continuous
internal and external illumination configurations as indicated in the tables in
§§
156.35 through
156.42 for each sign type.
         (c)   Temporary signs shall not be illuminated.
      (2)   Standards.
         (a)   Signs that are illuminated shall not operate at brightness
levels of more than 0.5 foot-candles (5.38 lux) above ambient light conditions
at the property line, as measured using a foot-candle meter. Illumination
levels shall be measured in foot-candles with a meter sensor in a horizontal
position at an approximate height of three feet above grade.
         (b)   Illumination shall not include animation, moving video, or
flashing, scrolling, intermittent, moving lights, rotating beams or flashing
beacon lights.
         (c)   Signs that are illuminated shall not be illuminated by flashing,
intermittent, or moving lights or lights that consist of an image projected
upon a stationary object.
         (d)   The illumination source for a sign or building shall be shielded
from view from any point on the ground by either an opaque or translucent
material.
         (e)   Illumination shall comply with all applicable provisions of the
city's Adopted Electrical Code.
         (f)   Signs with illumination in or within 100 feet of a residential
area shall be reduced to 50% of the maximum brightness level allowed by this
subchapter between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m.
   (B)   Electronic message centers.
      (1)   Generally.
         (a)   A sign that incorporates an electronic message center (EMC)
means a sign that displays a digital copy, including any illuminated sign on
which the illumination is not kept stationary or constant in intensity and
color when the sign is in use, including any light emitting diode (LED) or
digital panel, and which varies in color or intensity.
         (b)   Permanent signs may incorporate EMCs as indicated in the tables
in §§
156.35 through
156.42 for each sign type.
         (c)   Temporary signs shall not incorporate EMCs.
      (2)   Standards.
         (a)   Hold time.
            1.   Each message on the sign must be displayed for at least 15
seconds duration.
            2.   Message changes shall be completed instantaneously and shall
be imperceptible.
         (b)   Electronic copy.
            1.   Signs incorporating EMCs shall only contain static messages
changed exclusively by dissolve or fade transitions, and shall not have
movement or the appearance or optical illusion of movement during the static
display period of any part of the sign.
            2.   A static message shall not include any flashing or varying of
light intensity, and the message shall not scroll.
            3.   The change of message using dissolve or fade transition shall
not exceed two seconds of time between each message displayed on the sign.
         (c)   Brightness.
            1.   The intensity of the light source for an EMC shall not produce
glare, the effect of which constitutes a traffic hazard or is otherwise
detrimental to the public health, safety, or welfare.
            2.   An EMC shall not operate at brightness levels of more than 0.5
foot-candles (5.38 lux) above ambient light conditions at the property line, as
measured using a foot-candle meter. Illumination levels shall be measured in
foot-candles with a meter sensor in a horizontal position at an approximate
height of three feet above grade.
            3.   Prior to the issuance of a sign permit, the applicant shall
provide written certification from the sign manufacturer that the light
intensity has been factory pre-set not to exceed 0.5 foot-candles (5.38 lux)
above ambient light and that the intensity level is protected by the end-user
of the sign.
         (d)   Technology.
            1.   The technology currently being deployed for EMCs is Light
Emitting Diode (LED), but there may be alternate, preferred, or superior
technology available in the future that may be considered by the Director.
            2.   Any other technology that complies with the performance
standards for EMCs, including the maximum brightness levels as stated in §§
156.20 through
156.25 is permitted.
         (e)   Automatic shutoff. An EMC shall:
            1.   Have automatic dimmer software or solar sensors to control
brightness for nighttime viewing and variations in daytime ambient light;
            2.   Include systems and monitoring to either turn the display off,
show "full black" on the display, or include a default mechanism that freezes
the sign in one position if a malfunction occurs;
            3.   Be designed so that a catastrophic power surge will cause the
sign to go dark or to deploy the maximum brightness limitations; and
            4.   Automatically adjust the intensity of its display according to
natural ambient light conditions.
         (f)   Resolution.
            1.   EMC faces shall have a pixel pitch of no more than 16
millimeters.
               a.   PIXEL PITCH means a measurement of the resolution of a
digital display, in terms of the distance (generally in millimeters) between
the center of a LED cluster (pixel) and the center of the next LED pixel.
               b.   A lower pixel pitch measurement indicates a higher display
resolution.
            2.   This section only applies to sign(s) that are constructed,
rebuilt, or replaced after the effective date of this chapter.
      (3)   Maintenance.
         (a)   The sign owner shall provide the Director with the phone number
and email address of a person who is available to be contacted at any time and
who is able to turn off the EMC promptly after a malfunction occurs.
         (b)   The light modules on EMCs shall be repaired or replaced as they
become broken, burned-out, or substantially dimmed.
   (C)   Changeable copy.
      (1)   Generally. Permanent signs may incorporate changeable copy as
indicated in the tables in §§ 156.35 through 156.42 for each sign type.
      (2)   Standards. Changeable copies may be illuminated if the dimensions
and standards allow illumination for the sign type in the particular Sign
District.
   (D)   Neon.
      (1)   Generally.
         (a)   Only permanent, attached signs within the boundaries of the DTC
(Downtown Core Overlay), as defined in the zoning ordinance, may incorporate
neon. Although overlays are not otherwise used for regulating sign features in
this chapter, the DTC is maintained as an exception due to its distinct
character and design standards applicable to the downtown area regardless of
underlying zoning.
         (b)   Temporary signs shall not incorporate neon.
      (2)   Standards.
         (a)   Neon may be shaped to form objects or letters, or to outline
portions of a sign.
         (b)   Neon letters or characters may appear as a freestanding object,
mounted directly on a wall surface, mounted on a panel, or contained in open
channel letters.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
SIGN STANDARDS
§ 156.35 SIGN DISTRICTS AND SIGN ALLOCATIONS.
   (A)   Sign Districts. This chapter regulates signs by location. The city’s
zoning ordinance regulates use, setbacks, building size, site design, and land
use allowances by zoning districts. For the purposes of this chapter, zoning
districts are organized into sign districts to produce desirable sign outcomes.
The sign districts are established in Table 1: Sign Districts.

§ 156.36 DETACHED SIGNS.
   (A)   Detached signs are classified into one of the following sign types:
monument (major and minor) signs, pole (major and minor) signs, or subdivision
entry signs. Their associated regulations are established in this subchapter.
      (1)   A lot may have one detached sign, but not two or more unless
specified elsewhere in this section.
      (2)   A lot that has two or more road frontages may have no more than one
sign per frontage that does not exceed the maximum size in Table 2.
      (3)   No lot may have multiple detached signs of the same type with the
exception of multiple minor monument signs.
   (B)   Major monument signs.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/948048d06474cac31c32c8809bdeca24f7aca423/
IMAGES/0-0-0-8083.jpg]
      (1)   Definition. A permanent detached multi-tenant sign with a low
profile, a base, and a support structure with a solid appearance that is at
least 75% of the width of the widest part of the sign’s face.
      (2)   Standards.
         (a)   Generally.
   Table 2: Major Monument Sign Standards

         (b)   Number.
            1.   This section generally allows one double-sided major monument
sign for each lot fronting a street for the sign districts shown in Table 2:
Major Monument Sign Standards.
            2.   No major monument sign is allowed on a lot without frontage on
to a street.
         (c)   Design and installation.
            1.   When electrical service is provided to a major monument sign,
all electrical service shall be underground or concealed with the structure.
            2.   Major monument signs shall be designed to withstand wind loads
established by the Adopted Building Code.
            3.   All major monument signs shall be placed in concrete bases or
footings.
            4.   Major monument signs shall be constructed only of materials
that are noncombustible or slow-burning in the case of plastic inserts and
faces and may be supported by noncombustible material only, and finished in a
presentable manner. Untreated or non- engineered wood or non-painted steel
supports are specifically prohibited.
            5.   The design, materials, and finish of an individual major
monument sign shall be designed and finished to a standard that is similar to
the principal building or buildings on the lot.
            6.   Major monument signs may be composed of a changeable copy or
an electronic message center based on the standards in §
156.25 and the allowances for these features established in Table 2: Major
Monument Sign Standards.
   (C)   Minor monument signs.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/948048d06474cac31c32c8809bdeca24f7aca423/
IMAGES/0-0-0-8085.jpg]
      (1)   Definition. A permanent detached single-tenant sign with a low
profile, a base, and a support structure with a solid appearance that is at
least 75% of the width of the widest part of the sign’s face.
      (2)   Standards.
         (a)   Generally.

         (b)   Number.
            1.   This division generally allows one double-sided minor monument
sign for each lot fronting a street for the sign districts shown in Table 3:
Minor Monument Sign Standards, unless the lot fronts multiple arterial or
collector streets, in which case an additional minor monument sign is allowed
for each street frontage.
            2.   No minor monument sign is allowed on a lot without frontage on
to a street.
         (c)   Design and installation.
            1.   When electrical service is provided to a minor monument sign,
all electrical service shall be underground or concealed with the structure.
            2.   Minor monument signs shall be designed to withstand wind loads
established by the Adopted Building Code.
            3.   All minor monument signs shall be placed in concrete bases or
footings.
            4.   Minor monument signs shall be constructed only of materials
that are noncombustible or slow-burning in the case of plastic inserts and
faces and may be supported by noncombustible material only, and finished in a
presentable manner. Untreated or non-engineered wood or non-painted steel
supports are specifically prohibited.
            5.   The design, materials, and finish of an individual minor
monument sign shall be designed and finished to a standard that is similar to
the principal building or buildings on the lot.
            6.   Minor monument signs may be composed of a changeable copy or
an electronic message center based on the standards of §
156.25 and the allowances for these features established in Table 3: Minor
Monument Sign Standards.
   (D)   Major pole signs.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/948048d06474cac31c32c8809bdeca24f7aca423/

      (1)   Definition. A permanent detached multi-tenant sign in which the
sign face is mounted on one or more poles and the base of the sign face is
situated more than 12 inches above the ground. A major pole sign does not
include a flag mounted on a flagpole.
      (2)   Standards.

         (c)   Location. No major pole sign is allowed on a lot without

specifically prohibited.

            5.   When electrical service is provided to a major pole sign, all
electrical service shall be underground or concealed with the structure.

   (F)   Subdivision entry signs.

      (1)   Definition. A specific detached sign, either in the form of a minor
monument sign or double poled/columned sign, located at the entry of a platted
subdivision from a local, collector, or arterial street.

         (b)   Number and location. Subdivision entry signs may be located at
the intersection of a collector or arterial street and an entry street or
private driveway into a subdivision. The signs shall be configured as follows:
            1.   Two single-sided signs each located on opposite sides of the
entry street or private driveway;
            2.   One double-sided sign located within a landscaped area
dividing two one-way entry streets or private driveways;
            3.   One single-sided sign located on one side of the entry street
or private driveway; or
            4.   One single-sided sign located on either side of the entry
street or private driveway that spans the street and complies with §
156.36.
         (c)   Design and installation.
            1.   Generally.
               a.   A subdivision entry sign and its supporting structures may
be permitted in a public right-of-way pursuant to §
156.57.
               b.   Subdivision entry signs shall be constructed with stone,
brick, concrete, metal, routed wood planks or beams, or similar durable,
weatherproof materials.
               c.   When electrical service is provided to a subdivision entry
sign, all electrical service shall be underground.
            2.   Interaction with public right-of-ways. A subdivision entry
sign and its supporting structures may project into a public right-of-way
pursuant to §
156.57  and when the following conditions are met:
               a.   A minimum vertical clearance of 14 feet is provided from
the base of the sign and its supporting structures to the surface of the public
right-of-way;
               b.   All sign supporting structures (i.e., vertical piers,
columns, posts, etc.) shall be set back at least five feet from the edge of
curb; and
               c.   In no instance shall a subdivision entry sign and its
supporting structures exceed 25 feet in height.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.37 ATTACHED SIGNS.
   Attached signs are classified into one of the following sign types: wall
signs, attached awning/canopy signs, hanging signs, grounded canopy signs,
marquee signs, projecting signs or window signs. Their associated regulations
are established in this section. A building may have multiple attached signs,
unless specified elsewhere in this section.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/948048d06474cac31c32c8809bdeca24f7aca423/
IMAGES/0-0-0-8095.jpg]
      (1)   Definition. A permanent attached sign (other than an incidental
sign) that is affixed on an exterior building wall, and projects less than 18
inches from the wall to which it is attached (this projection includes
letters).
      (2)   Standards.
   (a)   Generally.
   Table 7: Wall Sign Standards
   Table 7: Wall Sign Standards
Sign District AG SF MF CM MU IN
Requirement
   Table 7: Wall Sign Standards

             only sf = square feet ft = feet “-” = the standard does not apply
 
      (3)   Number. There is no limit to the amount of wall signs allowed on a
building; however, in no instance shall the cumulative wall sign allowance
exceed the requirements in Table 7: Wall Sign Standards, unless specified
otherwise in this chapter.
      (4)   Design and installation.
         1.   A wall sign shall affix flush against the wall of the building or
as flush as possible while allowing the plane of the face of the sign to remain
perpendicular to the ground.
         2.   The wall sign's face shall not extend more than 18 inches from
the surface of the wall to which it is attached.
         3.   A wall sign shall be located below the building's roof line or in
instances where a parapet exists, located on the parapet.
   (B)   Attached awning/canopy signs.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/948048d06474cac31c32c8809bdeca24f7aca423/

to any facet of the covering or frame structure of an awning or attached
structural canopy.

      (1)   Definition. A permanent attached sign that is affixed to a grounded
canopy. A grounded canopy is a permanent structure that is structurally
independent of a building affixed to the ground, that is of rigid construction,
and over which a covering is attached that provides weather protection,
identity, or decoration.

§ 156.38 INCIDENTAL SIGNS.
   Incidental signs are classified into one of the following sign types:
detached way finding and directional signs. Their associated regulations are
established in this section. A lot may have multiple incidental signs as
allowed in this section.
   (A)   General incidental signs.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/948048d06474cac31c32c8809bdeca24f7aca423/
IMAGES/0-0-0-8112.jpg]
      (1)   Definition. A small permanent sign that is freestanding in addition
to the primary sign types for the property, such as detached signs and attached
signs, and that has a height and scale that is clearly subordinate to the
primary sign types (monument signs, pole signs, wall signs, etc.) allowed for
the property. Examples of typical general incidental signs include house
numbers, occupant directories, property or tenant identification names or
numbers, wayfinding signs, and directional signs, and signs warning the public
against trespassing or danger from animals. The list of examples is not
exhaustive and is provided to clarify the regulations and does not limit the
content of general incidental signs. The city will not review the content of
general incidental signs.
      (2)   Standards.

§ 156.39 TEMPORARY SIGNS.
   Temporary signs are classified into one of the following sign types: general
temporary signs, sidewalk signs, attached banners, detached banners, or feather
signs. Their associated regulations are established in this section. A building
or lot may have multiple temporary signs as allowed in this section. A
temporary sign shall not be used as a placeholder for detached and attached
signs unless specified elsewhere in this chapter.
   (A)   General temporary signs.
      (1)   Definition. A sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric,
cardboard, wood, wallboard, metal, high-density or corrugated plastic, or other
light materials, with or without frames, which is intended to be displayed for
a limited period of time only. Examples of typical general temporary signs
include political signs, public demonstrations, contractor or service-based
signs (such as those for construction, repairs, installation, landscaping,
cleaning, or other on-site services), grand opening signs, garage sale signs
and signs that announce an event such as a carnival, circus, or similar event.
The list of examples is not exhaustive and is provided to clarify the
regulations and does not limit the content of general temporary signs. The city
will not review the content of general temporary signs.
      (2)   Standards.
         (a)   Generally.
   Table 15: General Temporary Sign Standards

         (b)   Duration.
            1.   A general temporary sign may be displayed for:
               a.   No more than 30 consecutive days, three times during a
calendar year, separated by at least 14 calendar days.
            2.   The number of days for a general temporary sign shall not be
carried over to another display duration.
         (c)   Design and installation.
            1.   A detached general temporary sign shall be securely and firmly
embedded in or on the ground.
            2.   A detached general temporary sign may not deflect more than
ten degrees from vertical, unless designed to move or bend structurally with
the wind.
            3.   A detached general temporary sign shall not use sandbags or
other weighted objects to secure the sign to or in the ground.
            4.   No general temporary sign shall use an adhesive (tape, glue,
etc.) to affix the sign to any surface.
         (d)   Exemptions for general temporary signs within a residential
buffer.
            1.   General temporary signs located within a ten foot buffer
surrounding a residential dwelling shall be exempt from regulations, provided
that the following conditions are met:
               a.   The sign is placed entirely within the ten foot buffer
surrounding the residence; and
               b.   The total sign area does not exceed 20 square feet.
            2.   Examples of signs qualifying for this exemption include, but
are limited to signs expressing noncommercial, personal messages such as:
               a.   Academic achievement signs (e.g., honor student
recognition);
               b.   Collegiate affiliation signs; and
               c.   Other noncommercial expressional of personal milestones,
service, or affiliation (e.g., military service, graduation, birthdays, or
similar personal celebrations).
         (e)   Exceptions for temporary signs on active or transitional sites.
The following additional temporary signs are permitted on certain lots based on
their development status or use transition. These signs are allowed in addition
to the baseline allowances in Table 15, and may exceed the standard height,
area, setback, and duration limitations, provided they comply with the specific
standards outlined below:
            1.   Signs on lots with active development or building permits. One
temporary sign is allowed per street frontage on any lot with an active
building permit or approved site development permit.
               a.   Maximum sign area:
                  (i)   Eight square feet in residential districts.
                  (ii)   One hundred square feet in nonresidential districts.
               b.   Maximum height for non-residential districts. 15 feet.
               c.   Duration. Must be removed within seven days of the closure
of the building permit or final inspection approval.
            2.   Signs on undeveloped, unplatted, or vacant property. One
temporary sign is allowed per street frontage, with a maximum of two signs per
lot.
               a.   Minimum separation: 500 feet between signs on the same lot.
               b.   Minimum setback: 50 feet from the property line or right-
of-way, whichever is greater.
               c.   Maximum sign area: 100 square feet.
               d.   Maximum height: 15 feet.
               e.   Duration: Must be removed within 30 days after the property
is sold, leased, or occupied.
            3.   Signs for property under lease, sale, or occupancy transition.
One temporary sign is allowed per lot where a building, unit, or site is
actively for sale, lease, or undergoing a change of occupancy or use.
               a.   Residential property:
                  (i)   Maximum sign area: 8 square feet.
                  (ii)   Non-illuminated.
               b.   Nonresidential property:
                  (i)   Maximum sign area: 100 square feet.
                  (ii)   Shall not exceed the height of the building wall.
               c.   Duration: Must be removed within seven days of lease or
sale completion.
            4.   Temporary subdivision or development phase signs. One
temporary sign is allowed per subdivision entrance or development phase to
provide information related to lot availability, models, or development status.
               a.   Maximum sign area: 100 square feet.
               b.   Maximum height: 15 feet.
               c.   Duration: Must be removed within seven days of the final
sale or lease of all lots in the associated phase.
            5.   General conditions for all signs in this section. All signs
permitted under this section:
               a.   Must be located entirely on private property with the
consent of the owner.
               b.   Shall not be illuminated or contain electronic message
centers.
               c.   Are not subject to the height, area, duration, and setback
limitations in Table 15, unless specifically stated within the applicable
section.
               d.   Where a specific standard is not provided for a sign's
height, area, setback, or duration, the corresponding limitation in Table 15
shall apply by default.
         (f)   State law exemptions and regulations for political signs.
            1.   Per the Tex. Election Code § 259.003 the city may not, for a
sign that contains primarily a political message and that is located on private
real property with the consent of the property owner:
               a.   Prohibit the sign from being placed;
               b.   Require a permit or approval of the municipality, or impose
a fee for the sign to be placed;
               c.   Restrict the size of the sign; or
               d.   Provide for a charge for the removal of a political sign
that is greater than the charge for removal of other signs regulated by
ordinance.
            2.   Division (A)(2)(e)1. above does not apply to a sign, including
a billboard, that contains primarily a political message on a temporary basis
and that is generally available for rent or purchase to carry commercial
advertising or other messages that are not primarily political.
            3.   Division (A)(2)(e)1. above does not apply to a sign that:
               a.   Has an effective area greater than 36 feet;
               b.   Is more than eight feet high;
               c.   Is illuminated; or
               d.   Has any moving elements.
   (B)   Sidewalk signs.

dry-erase board.

§ 156.40 SPECIAL SIGNS.
