§ 156.41 VEHICLE SIGNS.
   (A)   Permit not required . Signs on vehicles do not require a sign permit
but must comply with this section.
   (B)   Vehicle used as a sign. No vehicle (including trailers or other non-
motorized wheeled vehicles carrying signs) shall be parked so that it functions
primarily as a sign unless exempt by §§ 156.20 through 156.25.
   (C)   Factors. Factors to determine whether a vehicle is being used
primarily as a sign include, but are not limited to the following:
      (1)   Is the vehicle parked at a prominent location on the lot?
      (2)   Is the vehicle inoperative and displaying a message?
      (3)   Is the sign easily read by a person in the right-of-way?
      (4)   Is the vehicle parked at the same or similar locations for several
hours during the same day or for several days during the same week?
      (5)   Does the vehicle use lights to display a message, including LEDs,
strobes, or incandescent bulbs?
      (6)   Are there any stated or apparent reasons, other than its function
as a sign, that justify the presence of the vehicle at that location?
   (D)   Presumption of use as a sign. While other factors may also establish a
violation, a vehicle presumptively violates this provision if the first five
questions are affirmative and there is no compelling answer to the sixth
question to justify the parking location as opposed to some less conspicuous
location.
   (E)   Limitations on vehicle signs. Vehicles (including trailers) may have
signs subject to the following limitations;
      (1)   Paper signs, electronic message signs, fabric signs, changeable
copy signs, or signs with a scrolling mechanism to change messages are not
allowed.
      (2)   The vehicle must have current state registration and be maintained
in running order.
      (3)   Signage is limited to a copy that is professionally painted or
printed on vinyl wrap that is maintained in good condition and is not faded or
torn.
      (4)   A vehicle displaying a sign shall be parked no closer than ten feet
from a right-of-way and shall not occupy a parking space, fire lane, or drive
aisle that is required for the principal use on the property.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.42 HISTORICAL SIGNS.
   Certain signs within the city which have been designated as a historical
sign by City Council action shall comply with the requirements of this section.
   (A)   Designation. Based on a survey of potential historic signs produced by
the city and any public nomination of a sign for historical status, the City
Council shall designate the sign or signs which it deems historically
significant as a historical sign. A sign may qualify as a historical sign if
it:
      (1)   Is or has been associated with a business enterprise or public
activity which has made significant contribution to the growth and development
of Cleburne or Johnson County;
      (2)   Is an example of distinctive architectural design prior to the
adoption of this chapter;
      (3)   Is associated with the contributions of a culturally significant
personality, building, or landmark; or
      (4)   Is not dilapidated or deteriorated to a point where it constitutes
a public hazard.
   (B)   Property owner support. The designation of any sign as a historical
sign must be requested by the property owner for designation and the property
owner's commitment for continued maintenance.
   (C)   Continued nonconformance and exemption. A sign which has been
designated as a historical sign is exempt from the standards of this chapter
except those that regulate maintenance. Any maintenance of the sign or
preservation work on the sign which may negate the sign's right to remain in
place as a nonconforming sign will not trigger a requirement to meet the
standards of this chapter in the case of a historical sign. In addition, any
work on the sign for the purpose of restoration or preservation which may
exceed 50% of the cost of replacement shall not trigger a requirement to meet
the standards of this chapter.
   (D)   Demolition. Any demolition permit sought which would lead to or
require the demolition of a sign designated as a historical sign shall be
delayed for 90 days from the date of application for a demolition permit so
that alternate locations for, or other dispositions of, the sign may be
arranged. If a workable alternative is not brought forth within the 90-day
demolition delay period, the sign may be demolished. However, if an alternate
location is agreed upon by the City Council, the demolition permit delay shall
continue for a reasonable period to allow implementation of the alternative. In
no case shall the total demolition delay exceed 120 days.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
PROCEDURES
§ 156.55 SIGN PERMIT.
   (A)   Applicability.
      (1)   A person shall not erect, construct, alter, repair, or relocate any
sign within the city without first obtaining a permit, except as provided for
in this chapter.
      (2)   Sections 156.35 through 156.42 establishes the permitting
requirements for each sign type in each Sign District.
      (3)   Any sign proposed on public property (if city property) must have
prior approval of the City Manager for temporary signs or City Council for
permanent signs to allow the sign.
      (4)   Any sign proposed on private property must have authorization by
the owner of that property to allow the sign.
      (5)   Modifications to an existing sign that consist of a changing of the
sign cabinet, frame, structural support, electrical componentry, or other
structural element will require a permit in accordance with this chapter.
   (B)   Applications.
      (1)   Each sign permit shall require a separate application.
      (2)   The application shall be submitted through the permitting process
and shall include a non-refundable fee set by the City Council.
      (3)   An applicant shall provide the information as required below:
         (a)   All applications for a sign permit shall include a professional
quality colored, drawing with scalable dimensions of the proposed sign showing
the height, width, setbacks, coverage, and areas, as regulated by this chapter.
         (b)   The submittal shall also include a drawing of the building
façade, indicating the proposed location of the sign (if building mounted) and
specifications.
      (4)   The Director may require the submittal of other pertinent
information and/or documentation when, in their opinion, that information is
necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter.
      (5)   An electrical permit may be required for signage utilizing either
new or existing electrical wiring or connections. The Director shall examine
the plans and specifications submitted with the application to ensure
compliance with the city's Adopted Electrical Code. No sign shall be erected
that violates the city's Adopted Electrical Code.
      (6)   All sign drawings and specifications submitted in accordance with
this chapter shall have the seal of a licensed engineer on all structural and
electrical details and specifications or as applicable per the Director.
   (C)   Review.
      (1)   The Director will review a sign permit application to determine if
it is complete. If the application is incomplete, the Director will provide a
list of items necessary to complete the application within ten business days
after the application was submitted.
      (2)   Based on the type of sign and Sign District as provided in §§
156.35 through
156.42, the Director will review a complete sign permit application for
compliance with this chapter and:
         (a)   Approve the permit; or
         (b)   Issue comments requesting revisions to the permit application.
      (3)   Complete applications that are subject to City Council review and
approval will be placed on the next available agenda.
   (D)   Approval criteria. A permit will be issued if the proposed sign
conforms with all applicable provisions of this chapter and any conditions or
stipulations of any applicable Zoning, Specific Use Permit, Site Plan, Planned
Development, or other Development Plan.
   (E)   Expiration. The Director may void a sign permit if installation does
not commence within six months from the permit approval date. If work
authorized by the permit is suspended or abandoned for 45 calendar days from
the date the work commences, the Director may require a new permit to complete
the installation work, even if no changes are made to the original sign permit.
   (F)   Revocation. The Director may revoke a sign permit and order the
modification or removal of the sign if:
      (1)   It is issued in error;
      (2)   It is reasonably foreseeable that the sign may partially or
completely fall in the event of an accident.
      (3)   The sign or sign supporting structure is installed contrary to the
approved permits and plans or in violation of this chapter.
   (G)   Sign maintenance.
      (1)   The repair, routine maintenance, or repainting of an existing sign
deemed conforming or allowed to continue as a nonconforming sign by §§
156.70 and
156.71 does not require a sign permit.
      (2)   Changing the face of a sign shall not require a sign permit,
provided that such a change is made to an existing sign face, without changing
the sign type, height, size or shape.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.56 MASTER SIGN PLAN.
   (A)   Purpose. A Master Sign Plan establishes parameters for the size,
location, and design of signs on a property being constructed or managed as a
unified development or large standalone development to ensure long term
aesthetic compatibility of signage throughout the development.
   (B)   Applicability.
      (1)   A Master Sign Plan is required for:
         (a)   Any nonresidential development that is a part of a Planned
Development greater than five acres and containing two or more buildings;
         (b)   Any unified development in the MU or CM Sign Districts greater
than five acres and containing two or more buildings; or
         (c)   Any nonresidential building greater than 50,000 square feet.
      (2)   A Master Sign Plan shall be submitted to determine:
         (a)   Overall sign locations on a property;
         (b)   The relationship of the signs to surrounding existing, proposed,
and future improvements; and
         (c)   Consistency and uniformity among buildings and signs within the
proposed development.
   (C)   Applications.
      (1)   The application shall be submitted through the permitting process
or as part of the Planned Development application and shall include a non-
refundable fee set by the City Council.
      (2)   An applicant shall provide the information as required below:
         (a)   A professional quality, colored drawing with scalable dimensions
of the proposed signs showing the height, width, setbacks, coverage, and areas,
as regulated by this chapter;
         (b)   A professional quality, colored drawing of the building façade,
indicating the proposed location of the signs (if building mounted) and
specifications; and
         (c)   A professional quality, colored drawing of the site plan
indicating the proposed location of the detached signs and distances from
property lines and structures.
   (D)   Review.
      (1)   The Director will review the Master Sign Plan to determine if it is
complete. If the Master Sign Plan is incomplete, the Director will provide a
list of items necessary to complete the plan within ten business days after the
application was submitted.
      (2)   Once the application is deemed complete, the Director will review
the Master Sign Plan for compliance with this chapter and within ten business
days:
         (a)   Approve the plan; or
         (b)   Issue comments for requested revisions to the plan.
   (E)   Approval criteria. A Master Sign Plan shall be issued if the applicant
can demonstrate to the Director that all signs:
      (1)   Meet the intent of applicable requirements of this chapter;
      (2)   Are appropriately related in form, proportion, scale, color,
materials, surface treatment, overall sign size and the size and style of
lettering to the function and design character of the building or premise on
which they will be displayed;
      (3)   Are placed in a logical location in relation to the overall
composition of the building's façade, orientation, or location; and
      (4)   Use consistent mounting, and coordinate mounting location(s) with
the architectural features of the principal buildings on the site.
   (F)   Appeal . The applicant may appeal the Director's decision to the City
Council pursuant to §
156.60.
   (G)   Expiration.
      (1)   A Master Sign Plan may expire if installation does not commence
within one year from the plan approval date. If work authorized by the plan is
suspended or abandoned for 45 calendar days from the date the work commences,
the Director may require a new plan to complete the installation work, even if
no changes are made to the original Master Sign Plan.
      (2)   A Master Sign Plan included within a Planned Development
Application may expire subject to the expiration of Planned Developments, as
outlined in Section 155.5.08.B of the Zoning Ordinance.
      (3)   In hearing the appeal, the Director will place the item on the next
available City Council agenda. The City Council shall review the Director's
decision, and then act on the appeal. The City Council's decision is final.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.57 SIGNS IN THE PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY.
   (A)   Generally. In certain circumstances, a sign may be located within the
public right-of-way provided that the applicant (if not the city) is granted a
right-of-way or license agreement to locate such a sign and its supporting
structures, in accordance with the requirements set forth in this section.
   (B)   City Council authorization. The City Council may, by duly executed
right-of-way or license agreement or by delegation to city staff, grant the
exclusive right to design and maintain a sign within the public right-of-way,
provided that it does not constitute a traffic safety hazard.
   (C)   Sign proposal. Prior to erecting any sign within the public right-of-
way, the applicant shall submit a Sign Proposal including location,
orientation, number of individual signs, and any other information deemed
necessary by the Director.
   (D)   Sign criteria. Signs located in the public-right-of-way shall:
      (1)   Not interfere with the use of the public streets, sidewalks,
walkways, bike and hiking trails;
      (2)   Comply with the intersection visibility requirements of the city;
      (3)   Not obstruct the visibility of motorists, pedestrians, or traffic
control signs; and
      (4)   Not be installed in immediate vicinity of street intersections, if
that sign is a detached sign.
   (E)   The applicant shall be responsible for all construction, installation,
maintenance, and repair of any sign for which a right-of-way or license
agreement is granted. Cost associated with the construction, installation,
maintenance, and repair by the applicant shall not be a cost to the city.
   (F)   Approval procedures for signs in the public right-of-way.
      (1)   All signs in public right-of-way shall have a right-of-way or
license agreement between the applicant and the city.
      (2)   The application for a right-of-way or license agreement shall
include the types, locations, size, area, height, number, materials, design,
and construction of all proposed signs.
      (3)   The application will be submitted to and reviewed by the Director
and once complete, will be placed on the next available City Council agenda.
      (4)   The City Council shall approve or disapprove the right-of-way or
license agreement.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.58 ALTERNATIVE COMPLIANCE.
   (A)   Purpose and application.
      (1)   Alternative compliance provides limited administrative flexibility
to address unique physical or site-specific conditions that make full
compliance with the sign regulations impractical.
      (2)   A request for alternative compliance may be submitted for review
and approval with the Sign Permit or Master Sign Plan.
   (B)   Review.
      (1)   The Director will review a request for alternative compliance to
determine if it is complete.
      (2)   If the request is incomplete, the Director will provide a list of
items necessary to complete the application within ten business days.
      (3)   When the Director deems the application complete, the Director will
review the proposed request and:
         (a)   Approve the request; or
         (b)   Issue comments for requested revisions to the request.
   (C)   Approval criteria.
      (1)   The Director may approve alternative compliance from the standards
of this chapter related to sign size, height, location, number, or illumination
if the request meets all of the following:
         (a)   The request is based on physical site conditions such as
topography, utility locations, building configuration, landscaping, or other
permanent features that prevent compliance with standard regulations;
         (b)   The request does not increase the total number of signs
otherwise permitted for the site;
         (c)   The sign does not obstruct or interfere with driver visibility
or sight-distance triangles and complies with applicable safety and structural
standards;
         (d)   The requested deviation does not exceed 20% of the maximum sign
area or height, unless specifically allowed under division (D);
         (e)   The sign is constructed of durable, professional materials
commonly used in permanent signage, and its placement does not block building
entrances, doors, windows, or any access points required for pedestrian,
vehicular, or emergency entry;
         (f)   The sign maintains a consistent level of quality, scale, and
proportionality with existing signage on the same site; and
         (g)   The sign does not produce lighting glare or spillover that
adversely affects traffic or adjacent residential uses.
      (2)   Content neutrality clause.  No decision made under this section
shall be based on the sign's content, message, viewpoint, purpose, or the
identity of the speaker.
   (D)   Flexible standards. The Director may grant requests for alternative
compliance regarding the following standards, in addition to standards listed
in other sections of this chapter:
      (1)   Sign area.
         (a)   The sign area, up to 20% of the general allowance, if the sign
height decreases by one foot for every one square foot increase in sign area.
         (b)   Multiple wall signs located on the same building or storefront
wall if the cumulative wall sign area does not exceed 35% of the building or
storefront wall's area (excluding windows and doors).
      (2)   Sign height.
         (a)   The sign height may exceed the maximum allowance by up to 20% of
the general allowance, provided there is a proportional decrease in sign width
(up to 20%) as the sign extends above the max height.
         (b)   Increasing the effective height of the sign by approving a berm
of up to three feet if one or more of the following conditions are present:
            1.   Utility equipment blocks all or part of the sign;
            2.   Drainage/ponding issues threaten the structural integrity of
the sign; or
            3.   The sign is located within 200 feet of signs that are of equal
or greater height to the proposed sign including the berm.
      (3)   Sign consolidation.
         (a)   Replace one major monument sign with no more than three minor
monument signs on a multi-tenant lot with right-of-way frontage of at least 150
feet provided each sign is no more than 20% of the size allowed for a major
sign in the applicable Sign District.
         (b)   The Director may allow consolidation of multiple smaller signs
into one larger sign under a Master Sign Plan, provided the height is not
increased and driver visibility is preserved.
      (4)   Location adjustments.
         (a)   The Director may reduce required setbacks by up to 20% to
accommodate fixed obstructions such as utilities or easements.
         (b)   A sign may be placed within a required intersection sight
triangle only if:
            1.   There are no feasible alternatives; and
            2.   A certified traffic engineering study (based on AASHTO
guidelines) confirms that the location maintains safe and adequate visibility.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.59 VARIANCES.
   (A)   Authority.
      (1)   The City Council has the authority to hear and grant variances
related to the provisions of this chapter related to the utilization of all
signs.
      (2)   The City Council may authorize a variance to any restriction
established in this chapter or if alternative compliance cannot be achieved.
   (B)   Application. Any applicant who seeks to deviate from the terms of this
chapter may request a variance as a means of relief from the standards of this
chapter. The application must be submitted through the permitting process and
include a non-refundable application fee of $750.
   (C)   Review.
      (1)   The Director will review a variance application to determine if it
is complete.
      (2)   If the application is incomplete, the Director will provide a list
of items necessary to complete the application within ten business days.
      (3)   Once deemed complete, the Director will place the item on the next
available City Council agenda.
   (D)   Approval criteria. City Council may consider the following criteria
when granting a variance to the provisions in this chapter:
      (1)   Special conditions exist which are peculiar to the land, structure,
or building involved and are not applicable to other lands, buildings or
structures in the same vicinity. The city may attach conditions to granting all
or a portion of any variance necessary to achieve the purpose of this chapter;
      (2)   The strict interpretation of the provisions of this chapter would
deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by other properties in the
vicinity under the terms of this chapter. This condition of comparable
enjoyment does not apply to properties with signs that predate the adoption of
these restrictions nor those properties that hold vested rights of
nonconformance;
      (3)   The special conditions and circumstances do not result from the
actions of the applicant and such conditions and circumstances do not merely
constitute monetary hardship or inconveniences;
      (4)   Granting the variance will meet the objectives of this chapter and
not be injurious to the adjoining property owners or otherwise detrimental to
the public welfare;
      (5)   The request will be the minimum variance necessary to alleviate the
special hardship or practical difficulty faced by the applicant in meeting the
requirements of this chapter; and
      (6)   The variance remains consistent with the overall regulatory
framework of this chapter, excluding considerations related to sign content,
message, or viewpoint.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.60 APPEALS.
   (A)   Grievance as a condition for appeal. Any aggrieved person may appeal
the determination of the Director regarding a sign permit by filing an appeal.
   (B)   Appeals of administrative decisions.
      (1)   To determine the suitability of alternative materials and methods
of construction and provide for reasonable interpretation of the provisions of
this chapter, the City Council shall hear appeals about any decision of the
Director regarding a sign permit.
      (2)   Any appeal shall be brought by written application specifying the
grounds for the appeal, filed by the applicant of the sign permit with the
Director within ten business days following the action which is the subject of
the appeal.
      (3)   Enforcement of this chapter shall be stayed pending the appeal.
      (4)   The Director will place the item on the next available City Council
agenda. In hearing the appeal, the City Council shall review the Director's
decision, and then act on the appeal. The City Council's decision is final.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
NONCONFORMITIES AND ENFORCEMENT
§ 156.70 NONCONFORMING AND ABANDONED SIGNS.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   No sign shall be erected, reconstructed, or repaired after the
effective date of this chapter unless at least one of the following conditions
is satisfied:
         (a)   The erection, reconstruction, or repair meets all the provisions
of this chapter or any other applicable ordinance adopted by the city;
         (b)   An existing sign has rights of nonconformance;
         (c)   The work on a sign can be classified as ordinary maintenance; or
         (d)   Repairs are necessary to prevent a hazardous condition, as
determined by the Building Official or third-party engineer's certification.
Those repairs include major structural repair which affects the structural
integrity of the sign and constitutes a hazard to the public health, safety, or
welfare.
   (B)   Unlawful, discontinued, or abandoned signs. Unlawful, discontinued, or
abandoned signs are subject to the following:
      (1)   Notice and order. Any sign, abandoned sign, supporting structure,
or abandoned supporting structure which is erected, placed, relocated,
constructed, reconstructed, altered, displayed, maintained, installed,
modified, or used in violation of this chapter may be removed by the Director
as provided in this section. The Director shall deliver or send a written
notice and order to the owner of an unlawful, discontinued, or abandoned sign
or the owner of the premises where the unlawful sign is located. A notice and
order sent or delivered to the person listed by the district appraisal roll as
the owner of the premises where the unlawful, discontinued, or abandoned sign
is located shall be presumed to be sufficient. The notice and order shall:
         (a)   Describe the nature of the violation or the conditions that
substantiate abandonment with specific citation to relevant law;
         (b)   Order the correction of the violation or conditions that
substantiate abandonment within a time specified, which shall not be less than
30 business days from the mailing of the notice; and
         (c)   Give notice that the Director may remove and impound the
unlawful or discontinued or abandoned sign at the owner's expense if the
violation is not corrected within the time specified.
      (2)   Removal appeals.
         (a)   If the person ordered to correct a violation fails to do so
within the time specified, the Director may remove, or cause the removal of,
the unlawful or abandoned sign.
         (b)   Any person aggrieved by the order may file an appeal with the
City Council in which case the sign may remain in place until the Council
reaches its decision, unless the sign presents a threat to the public safety by
virtue of its physical condition.
      (3)   Impoundment, redemption, and disposal. The following applies to the
impoundment, redemption, or disposal of an unlawful or abandoned sign:
         (a)   Any sign which is removed by the Director pursuant to this
chapter shall be impounded, transported to, and stored by the Director at a
location designated for such purpose. Records shall be kept of the storage
location for that sign. The Director shall send a letter to the owner of that
sign, if known, or, if not known, to the owner or person in control of the
premises where the sign was located, giving notice of impoundment.
         (b)   The Director shall hold the sign in storage for at least 45
calendar days after notice of impoundment has been mailed. The city may recover
reasonable costs for hauling and storing the sign. Any portable sign may be
redeemed by the owner upon the payment of a fee to the city for hauling the
sign to storage, plus a per day storage fee. Any non-portable sign may be
redeemed by the owner upon payment of the cost of removal and hauling the sign
to storage, as determined by the Director, plus a per day storage fee. These
fees shall be established by the City Council.
         (c)   Any sign not reclaimed by the owner within 30 calendar days of
the mailing of the notice of impoundment may be disposed of in accordance with
applicable law.
      (4)   Recovery costs. If, upon disposal of an unredeemed non-portable
sign, the Director has not received an amount sufficient to cover the cost of
removal and hauling of the removed sign, the Director may send notice to the
owner of the premises where the sign was located, stating payment of the
removal and hauling costs, and any amount received in disposal of that sign.
Any remaining unpaid costs 30 calendar days from the date of mailing of notice
shall become delinquent and shall bear interest at 10% per annum. The cost
levied against the premises shall include an administration fee established by
the City Council.
      (5)   Appeal. Any person may contest the reasonableness of the cost of
removal of a sign imposed by filing of an appeal with the Director (for
consideration by the City Council) within 20 calendar days of the mailing of
the notice of the costs. The City Council may uphold the costs imposed by the
Director or impose and levee whatever costs the City Council considers
reasonable.
      (6)   Removal of hazardous signs.
         (a)   Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the
Director may remove any unlawful sign which, because of its location or
condition, clearly constitutes an immediate hazard or danger to the public.
         (b)   The Director must receive a written response from the Building
Official determining that the sign is hazardous or dangerous.
         (c)   The Building Official shall determine that the sign is hazardous
or dangerous by assessing if the sign or any sign component:
            1.   Is not securely attached;
            2.   Is torn, broken, damaged, hanging, or leaning more than 10%;
            3.   Displays unsecured wires or exposed lighting fixtures; or
            4.   Creates a similar effect that may constitute as a public
nuisance.
         (d)   Before removing the sign, the Director shall make a reasonable
attempt to locate the owner of the hazardous sign or person responsible for its
display, placement, or maintenance to give written notice of the violation, the
action necessary to correct the violation and time period in which the
correction must be made.
         (e)   The notice shall be delivered to the owner of the sign, the
owner of the premises, or the person responsible for the sign's display,
placement, or maintenance, if located; otherwise, the notice shall be affixed
to the sign or other prominent place on the premises likely to come to the
attention of the owner of the sign or premises.
         (f)   If no corrective action is taken within the time specified, the
city, upon a determination by City Council, may pursue injunctive action to
have the sign removed.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.71 ENFORCEMENT AND INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   The Director shall administer this chapter. The Director may delegate
duties and powers granted to and imposed upon the Director by this chapter.
   (B)   The Director is authorized to:
      (1)   Request additional submittal materials deemed necessary to
determine compliance;
      (2)   Inspect any sign, building, structure, or land to determine whether
any violations of this chapter exist;
      (3)   Approve or deny a permit in accordance with this chapter;
      (4)   Issue a notice of violation if a sign is constructed or being
constructed and does not comply with the requirements of this chapter; or
      (5)   Issue a notice of fine if the violation continues or is not
remedied within 14 calendar days of the receipt of a notice of violation.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
DEFINITIONS
§ 156.80 GENERALLY.
   (A)   Usage and interpretation rules. For the purpose of this chapter,
certain terms or words are interpreted or defined as follows:
      (1)   Words used in the present tense include the future tense;
      (2)   The singular includes the plural;
      (3)   The word PERSON includes a corporation, trust, individual, or group
of individuals;
      (4)   The term SHALL is always mandatory; and
      (5)   The term MAY is discretionary.
      (6)   A reference to a city official includes a designee of that
official.
      (7)   When the calculation of a number for a required standard result in
a fraction, that fraction is rounded up to the next whole number.
   (B)   Words and terms not expressly defined. Words and terms not expressly
defined in this chapter are to be construed according to the normally accepted
meaning of those words or terms. Where no definition appears for a term in this
chapter, then use the term's customary usage or definition in the practice of
planning, engineering, or building construction, as determined by the Director.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.81 STANDARD DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   ABANDONMENT. To cease or discontinue a use or activity other than short-term
interruptions to a use or activity during periods of remodeling, maintaining,
or otherwise improving or rearranging a facility, or during normal periods of
vacation or seasonal closure.
   ABUTTING. Adjacent, adjoining, and contiguous to. It may also mean having a
lot line in common with a right-of-way or easement, or with a physical
improvement such as a street, waterline, park, or open space.
   ADOPTED BUILDING CODE. The city's adopted building code, as amended.
   ALLEY. A public right-of-way, not intended to provide the primary means of
access to abutting lots, that is used primarily for vehicular service access to
the back or sides of properties otherwise abutting on a street.
   ALTER. To change the size, shape or outline, or type of sign.
   APPLICANT. The person or entity responsible for the submission of an
application. The applicant must be the actual owner of the property for which
an application is submitted, or a duly authorized representative of the
property owner.
   APPLICATION. The package of materials, including but not limited to an
application form, completed checklist, tax certificate, drawings or studies,
and other informational materials, that is required by the city to initiate
city review and approval of a development project.
   APPROVAL. Approval constitutes a determination by the Director or City
Council responsible for such determination that the application is in
compliance with the minimum provisions of this chapter.
   ARTERIAL.
      (1)   A street designated within the Master Thoroughfare Plan.
      (2)   A principal traffic way more or less continuous across the city or
areas adjacent thereto, intended primarily to provide for the movement of
through traffic, and that shall act as a principal connecting street with
highways as indicated in the Master Throughfare Plan.
   ATTACHED AWNING. An architectural projection from an exterior wall of a
building that provides weather protection, identity, or decoration, and is
partially or wholly supported by the building to which it is attached. An
awning is comprised of a lightweight frame structure over which a covering is
attached.
   ATTACHED CANOPY. An architectural projection from an exterior wall of a
building that is of rigid construction, is supported by attachment to a
building on one or more sides, and over which a covering is attached that
provides weather protection, identity, or decoration.
   BLINK. A light or light source that shines intermittently or unsteadily.
   BUILDING. Any structure built for support, shelter or enclosure of persons,
animals, personal property, records or other movable property and when
separated in a manner sufficient to prevent fire, each portion of such building
shall be deemed a separate building.
   BUILDING FACADE.
      (1)   PRIMARY FACADE. A façade that faces a public or private street or
street right-of-way, park, courtyard, or trail.
      (2)   SECONDARY FACADE. A façade that does not face a public or private
street or street right of way, park, courtyard, or trail.
      (3)   FRONT FACADE. The façade that contains a primary public entrance to
a building.
   CHANGEABLE COPY. A copy that can be changed or rearranged without altering
the sign face or structure, excluding electronic message centers.
   CITY. The City of Cleburne, Texas, together with all its governing and
operating bodies.
   CITY COUNCIL. The City Council of the city.
   CITY MANAGER. The City Manager of the city or their designee.
   COLLECTOR. A street that is continuous through several residential districts
and is intended as a connecting street between residential districts and
nonresidential districts, highways, or business districts, and that may serve
both through-traffic and local access functions.
   COPY. Logos, characters, symbols, or any other portion of a sign that
conveys a message or information.
   DEVELOPMENT. Any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate,
including but not limited to buildings or other structures, paving, drainage,
utilities, storage, and agricultural activities.
   DIRECTOR. The person designated by the City Manager to provide oversight for
and have responsibility of the city's planning and development related duties.
This term shall also include any designee of the Director, including the
Building Official.
   EASEMENT. A grant by a property owner of the use of land by the public, a
corporation, entity, or persons for specific purposes.
   EFFECTIVE DATE. The date this Sign Code or any subsequent amendment becomes
effective.
   ENGINEER. Per § 1001.002 of the State of Tex. Occupations Code, as may be
amended, ENGINEER means a person licensed to engage in the practice of
engineering in the State of Texas.
   ERECT. To build, construct, attach, hang, place, suspend or affix, and shall
also include:
      (1)   The painting of signs on the exterior surface of a building or
structure;
      (2)   The painting or affixing of signs to the exterior or interior
surface of windows; and
      (3)   Outdoor signs and signs located interior to a building but readily
visible from abutting property or right of way, unless the sign is located five
feet or more from a window or doorway.
   EXTERNAL ILLUMINATION. Illumination provided by an external light source
such as a lamp, bulb, or the like.
   FLASH or FLASHING. A light or light source that shines in a bright and
brief, sudden, or intermittent way.
   FLICKER. A light or light source that shines unsteadily and varies rapidly
in brightness.
   FRONTAGE. All the property abutting on one side of the street, or between
two intersecting streets, measured along the street line.
   GROUNDED CANOPY. A permanent structure that is structurally independent of a
building affixed to the ground, that is of rigid construction, and over which a
covering is attached that provides weather protection, identity, or decoration.
   IMPROVEMENT. Any man-made fixed item that becomes part of or placed upon
real property.
   INTERNAL ILLUMINATION. Illumination created by a light source internal to
the sign, transparent or translucent material from a light source within the
sign structure or panel, or exposed lighting located on the same plane as the
sign face.
   LOT. Land occupied, or to be occupied, by a building and its accessory
buildings and including such open spaces as are required under this chapter and
having its principal frontage on a public street or officially approved place.
   MARQUEE. A type of attached canopy that has a top surface that is typically
sloped less than 25 degrees from the horizontal, is located less than ten feet
above the top of an operable exterior doorway, and frequently includes panels
for changeable copy.
   NEON. A source of light supplied by a glass tube that is filled with neon
gas, argon, mercury, or other inert gas that produces ultraviolet light, and
bent to form letters, symbols, or other shapes. The term NEON is inclusive of
flexible light emitting diode (LED) technology that simulates neon. Generally,
neon includes:
      (1)   All tubular light sources that employ a charged gas to illuminate a
tube that glows;
      (2)   Similar gas-activated tubular light systems that emit colors; and
      (3)   Other tubular light sources (including fiber optics) that are used
to form letters and shapes.
   NONCOMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL. Any material that will not ignite at or below a
temperature of 1,200 degrees Fahrenheit (649 degrees Celsius) and will not
continue to burn or glow at that temperature or shall have a flame spread of 25
or less.
   PRINCIPAL BUILDING. The building that contains the primary function or
activity on a lot.
   PROPERTY LINES. The lines bounding a lot.
   PULSE/PULSATE. A single vibration or short burst of light.
   RESIDENTIAL AREA. Those areas where residential uses are the primary uses in
a residential zoning district.
   RIGHT-OF-WAY.
      (1)   A parcel of land occupied or intended to be occupied by a street or
alley or other transportation infrastructure.
      (2)   A right-of-way may be used for other facilities and utilities, such
as sidewalks, railroad crossings, electrical communication, oil or gas, water
or sanitary or storm sewer facilities, or for any other use.
      (3)   The use of right-of-way shall also include parkways and medians
outside of pavement.
   ROOF. The external upper covering of a building, including the frame for
supporting the roofing.
   ROOF LINE. The height that is defined by the intersection of the roof of the
building and the wall of the building.
   SETBACK. A line within a lot, parallel to and measured from a corresponding
lot line, establishing the minimum required yard and governing the placement of
structures and uses on the lot.
   SIGHT VISIBILITY TRIANGLE. A space left open and unobstructed by fences,
structures, shrubs, trees, or other plant life along streets at the corner in
front of the building line of lots contiguous to intersecting streets. Also
called INTERSECTION SIGHT TRIANGLE.
   SIGN CODE. The adopted sign regulations of the city, as may be amended in
the future, and may be referred as "the Sign Code".
   SIGN HEIGHT. The vertical distance measured from the highest point of a sign
to the ground or lowest grade beneath the sign.
   SIGN PERMIT. A permit authorizing the erection or maintenance of a sign
pursuant to this chapter.
   SIGN PROJECTION. The measured horizontal distance from the building wall to
the sign's outermost edge.
   SIGN STRUCTURE. Any combination of materials to form a construction for the
purpose of attaching, fixing, or otherwise supporting a sign, whether installed
on, above, or below the surface of the lot, a building, or any other solid
surface.
   SITE PLAN. A detailed, scaled drawing of all surface improvements,
structures, and utilities proposed for development and is associated with the
Zoning Ordinance.
   STOREFRONT. The facade or entryway of a store, shop, or business located
within a building. A building may have multiple storefronts which may be
located on any level of that building.
   STORY. That portion of a building included between the upper surface of a
floor and the upper surface of the floor or roof next above. Also, the vertical
distance between two successive tiers of beams or finished floor surfaces and,
for the topmost story, from the top of the floor finish to the top of the
ceiling joists or, where there is not a ceiling, to the top of the roof
rafters.
   STREET. A public right-of-way that provides vehicular traffic access to
adjacent lands or for the movement of through traffic.
   STRUCTURE. Anything constructed or erected that requires location on the
ground or attached to something having a location on the ground, including, but
not limited to freestanding canopies, pergolas, gazebos, carports, advertising
signs, billboards, and poster panels, but not including fences, retaining
walls, sidewalks, or curbs. For structures designed for habitation, see
BUILDING.
   SUBDIVISION.
      (1)   The division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more parts or
lots for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale or building
development or transfer of ownership with the exception of transfer to heirs of
an estate, and shall include re-subdivision.
      (2)   Any other subdivision or re-subdivision of land contemplated by the
provisions of Chapter 212, Tex. Local Gov’t Code.
   WALL AREA. The entire facade of a building where a wall sign is placed,
excluding all windows and doors of the facade.
   ZONING ORDINANCE. The adopted Zoning Ordinance of the city, as may be
amended in the future, and may be referred as "the Zoning Ordinance."
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.82 SIGN DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   ATTACHED AWNING/CANOPY SIGN. A sign painted, printed, attached, or otherwise
applied to any facet of the covering or frame structure of an awning or
attached structural canopy.
   ATTACHED BANNER. A temporary sign made of fabric, cloth, bunting, plastic,
paper, or any other non-rigid material with no enclosing framework that is
attached, mounted, tied, or otherwise placed on a building or pole attached to
a building. This definition does not include flags, pennants, or streamers.
   ATTACHED SIGN. Those signs that are affixed to a building or structure that
are established in § 156.37.
   DETACHED BANNER. A temporary, freestanding sign made of fabric, cloth,
bunting, plastic, paper, or any other non-rigid material with no enclosing
framework that affixes to the ground. This definition does not include flags,
pennants, or streamers.
   DETACHED SIGN. Those signs that are freestanding on a lot that are
established in § 156.36.
   DIGITAL BILLBOARD. A freestanding sign or sign structure upon which an
electronic copy is placed on a poster or panel and mounted on a pole or metal
structure typically with a monopole structure constructed with tubular steel
support, tubular steel framing, and a single display panel with a concrete
foundation.
   ELECTRONIC MESSAGE CENTER (EMC). A sign that displays a digital copy,
including any illuminated sign on which the illumination is not kept stationary
or constant in intensity and color when the sign is in use, including any light
emitting diode (LED) or digital panel, and which varies in color or intensity.
Electronic message centers are also referred to as digital signs, dynamic
signs, or changeable electronic variable message signs (CEVMS).
   FEATHER SIGN. A temporary, freestanding sign made of flexible material in
the shape of a feather, quill, sail, blade, or teardrop, and mounted on a solid
or flexible pole or cord that affixes to the ground.
   FLAG. A piece of fabric or other flexible material with distinctive colors
and patterns, customarily mounted on a pole or similar freestanding structure
or on a pole mounted on a building.
   GENERAL INCIDENTAL SIGN. A small permanent sign that is freestanding or
attached to a building that is in addition to the primary sign types for the
property, such as detached signs and attached signs, and that has a height and
scale that is clearly subordinate to the primary sign types allowed for the
property. Examples of typical general incidental signs include house numbers,
occupant directories, property or tenant identification names or numbers,
wayfinding signs, and directional signs, and signs warning the public against
trespassing or danger from animals. The list of examples is not exhaustive and
is provided to clarify the regulations and does not limit the content of
general incidental signs. The city will not review the content of general
incidental signs.
   GENERAL TEMPORARY SIGN. A sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric,
cardboard, wood, wallboard, metal, or other light materials, with or without
frames, which is intended to be displayed for a limited period of time only.
Examples of typical general temporary signs include political signs, public
demonstrations, grand opening signs, contractor signs (includes all licensed
trades such as roofing, plumbing, electrical work, etc.), real estate signs,
garage sale signs, and signs that announce an event such as a carnival, circus,
or similar event. The list of examples is not exhaustive and is provided to
clarify the regulations and does not limit the content of general temporary
signs. The city will not review the content of general temporary signs.
   GROUNDED CANOPY SIGN. A permanent attached sign that is affixed to a
grounded canopy.
   HANGING SIGN. A sign suspended from the underside of a canopy, awning,
ceiling, marquee, roof overhang, a covered porch, or walkway.
   INFLATABLE DEVICE. A type of balloon sign that is a cold air inflated
object, which may be of various shapes, made of flexible fabric, resting on the
ground or structure, and equipped with a portable blower motor that provides a
constant flow of air into the device. Inflatable devices are restrained,
attached, or held in place by a cord, rope, cable, or similar method.
   LED. The abbreviation for Light Emitting Diode.
   MAJOR MONUMENT SIGN. A permanent detached multi-tenant sign with a low
profile, a base, and a support structure with a solid appearance that is at
least 75% of the width of the widest part of the sign's face.
   MAJOR POLE SIGN. A permanent detached multi-tenant sign in which the sign
face is mounted on one or more poles and the base of the sign face is situated
more than 12 inches above the ground. A major pole sign does not include a flag
mounted on a flagpole.
   MARQUEE SIGN. A permanent attached sign affixed to a marquee.
   MINOR MONUMENT SIGN. A permanent detached single-tenant sign with a low
profile, a base, and a support structure with a solid appearance that is at
least 75% of the width of the widest part of the sign's face.
   MINOR POLE SIGN. A permanent detached single-tenant sign in which the sign
face is mounted on one or more poles and the base of the sign face is situated
more than 12 inches above the ground. A minor pole sign does not include a flag
mounted on a flagpole.
   MURAL. A hand-produced work in which paint is applied by hand directly on an
exterior wall of a building or structure. A mural does not include:
      (1)   Mechanically produced or computer-generated prints or images,
including digitally printed vinyl sheets and wraps;
      (2)   Works containing electrical or mechanical components; or
      (3)   Works that involve changing or moving images or components.
   NONCONFORMING SIGN. A sign that was lawfully in existence and was properly
permitted by the city, to the extent such permitting was required as of the
effective date of this chapter.
   PROJECTING SIGN. A permanent attached sign type that is affixed to and
projects 18 inches or more from the wall of a building and is generally
perpendicular to the building façade. A projecting sign does not include signs
located on an attached canopy, awning, marquee, or roof.
   REAL ESTATE AND HOME BUILDING SIGN. A temporary sign made of a wood or light
metal frame that is affixed to land that is for sale or is in the process of
development. Real estate signs are usually distinguished from permanent signage
by a lack of features such as engineered footings, structural reinforcement,
electrification, and permanent applied finishes and/or materials.
   SIDEWALK SIGN. A temporary and portable sign that is ordinarily in the shape
of an "A" or inverted "T" with back-to-back sign faces, an easel, or a similar
configuration to be located on a sidewalk or walkway.
   SIGN. A visual display of an object or device that includes elements such as
colors, lights, motion, symbols, images, icons, letters, numerals, figures,
characters, or combines any of those elements, that is intended to communicate,
advertise, identify, announce, direct, inform, or attract. The term SIGN
includes a structure used to support or display a sign.
   SIGN AREA. The area enclosed by the smallest imaginary regular shape (e.g.
parallelogram, triangle, circle, trapezoid) or combination of regular shapes
that will encompass the extreme limits of the writing, representation, emblem,
or other display, or combination thereof, together with any material or color
forming an integral part of the display or used to differentiate the sign from
the backdrop or structure against which it is placed. Sign area includes such
features as decorative or ornamental elements or features, borders, trims, but
not including the architectural enclosure or supporting structure which is used
solely for support of the sign, such as poles, columns and cables, pylons, or
other architectural enclosures.
   SUBDIVISION ENTRY SIGN. A specific detached sign, either in the form of a
minor monument sign or double poled/columned sign, located at the entry of a
residential subdivision from a local, collector, or arterial street.
   TEMPORARY SIGN. Those signs that are either freestanding on a lot or affixed
to a building or structure which are erected on a specified time period.
Temporary signs include all those signs established in § 156.39.
   WALL SIGN. A permanent attached sign (other than an incidental sign) that is
affixed on an exterior building wall, and projects less than 18 inches from the
wall to which it is attached (this projection includes letters).
   WINDOW SIGN. A sign posted, printed, placed, or affixed to a window or glass
door. A window sign includes any sign that is located inside a building, that
is three feet or less from a window or glass door, and that is intended to be
visible from outside the building.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
§ 156.99 PENALTIES.
   (A)   Any failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter constitutes
a violation of this chapter.
   (B)   The Director may institute any appropriate action proceedings to
prevent the unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, relocation,
alteration, repair, or use of any sign, and to restrain, correct, or abate such
violation. Penalties for violation are as follows:
      (1)   Violators of any provisions of this chapter shall be subject to
fines established in this section. Signs may be removed by agent and employees
of the city and may be either stored or destroyed without liability to the city
or its agents, or employees. The owner of a sign confiscated by the city may
claim the sign in the custody of the city for an administrative fee of $200 per
sign;
      (2)   Fines shall be assessed to those who violate §
130.03 and §
130.04 of the Cleburne Code of Ordinances; and
      (3)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter for which no
other penalty is established is subject to the penalties established in §
10.99 of the Cleburne Code of Ordinances.
(Ord. 06-2025-20, passed 6-10-25)
CHAPTER 157: MANAGEMENT OF THE RIGHT-OF-WAY
